loans.name: Amal

texts.en:
Amal is a 33 year-old young woman. She is married with two sons and two daughters. Amal is a religious woman, so her husband is photographed instead in a FATEN branch. Her husband is an industrial company employee with a decent salary. Amal wants to improve her family life by purchasing new home furniture such as bedroom furniture, living room furniture, etc. The amount of money she has isn't enough to pay for this purchase, so she needs to take out a loan from FATEN. When Amal gets the loan which is repaid on a monthly basis, she will be able to purchase new home furniture and offer her family better living conditions. 


About this loan product:
 FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the cultural context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit Kiva's Muslim World Lending helptext: http://tinyurl.com/3aekx8m.

loans.use: To purchase new home furniture.

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en:
Hoa is a 53-year old married mother of three children. She lives with her husband and children in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband is a hairdresser. 
Hoa runs a small general store, selling food products and household necessities in their community. She has been in this business for over 15 years. 

Hoa would like a loan to buy a greater variety and quantity of basic foods to stock her general store. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her existing customers and attract additional customers. She also hopes that through the loan, her business will generate a higher income. This will help her to improve her family's living conditions and enable her to save money for her family.

loans.use: To buy basic foods to stock her general store.

loans.name: Maria Rosario

texts.es:
Maria Rosario pertenece al banco comunal “Nueva Esperanza de Ollantaytambo” y las reuniones de las socias del banco comunal son cada treinta días en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo de la provincia de Urubamba del departamento del Cusco. 

Maria Rosario tiene 29 años de edad y es casada y fruto de esta unión  tiene un hijo, ella nació en la ciudad Ollantaytambo  y vive en la misma ciudad donde nació y donde realiza sus actividades económicas. Su actividad económica principal de Maria Rosario es la venta de comida y tiene un restaurante turístico en su domicilio por las mañana sirve desayuno turístico, al medio día sirve almuerzo a turistas y nacionales,  y por las noche hace pizzas. Ya es un año que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo.  

En esta oportunidad Maria Rosario requiere el préstamo para comprar insumos como por ejemplo, sacos de arroz, sacos de azúcar, aceite, harina, queso y otras cosas más.
 
Maria Rosario agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales.
texts.en:
María Rosario belongs to the Nueva Esperanza de Ollantaytambo communal bank, and the meetings of the bank members are every month in the city of Ollantaytambo, in the province of Urubamba, department of Cusco.

María Rosario, 29, is married and has one child from this relationship.  She was born in Ollantaytambo and lives in her native city, where she carries out her business.  Her main economic activity is selling food, and she has a restaurant for tourists in her home.  In the morning she serves breakfast to tourists, at noon she serves lunch to tourists and locals, and at night she makes pizza.  She has had this business for a year now and it's going very well for her, thanks to the effort she puts into her work.

María Rosario needs a loan now to buy supplies such as, for example, bags of rice, bags of sugar, oil, flour, cheese, and other things.

María Rosario is grateful for and values the loan, and she is committed to making her monthly payments.

loans.use: to buy bags of rice, bags of sugar, oil, flour, cheese, and other supplies

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet is 26 years old and lives in Masindi, Uganda. She is a single mother who desires to have a boutique. Juliet earned money from working at a bakery and used it to buy clothes to sell. Currently she is a market vendor whose major challenge is limited capital and rain. She wants a loan to buy clothes for resell.

loans.use: to buy clothes to resell.

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
This is Consuelo, 51, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a married to her husband Melchor, a vendor, and they have three children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Consuelo operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 pesos worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Celia earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippines pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of 13,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Consuelo dreams to be able to give all her children a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Asiaha

texts.en:
Asiaha is a 30 year old married woman with five children. Four of them are in school. She has had a business selling tea in Kator South Sudan for four years.
Asiaha requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase sugar. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase sugar for sale.

loans.name: Balimaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe BALIMAYA sont essentiellement des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans, et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles monogamiques à  HAMDALLAYE, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Madame  AICHATA  se tenant au milieu fait le commerce d’orange.
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt dix  paniers d’orange qu’elle revend en détail au marché de Médine à Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17 500 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en: The members of the BALIMAYA group are mostly married women who are on average 33 years old and have three children each.  Most of them live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the working-class neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso (third administrative district of Mali).  This is their first loan with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution; their goal is to meet their customers' needs.  Aichata is the woman standing in the middle.  Aichata buys and sells oranges.  With her loan, she is planning to buy ten baskets of oranges which she will sell for retail at the Médine market in Sikasso and also from her home, for cash, to mostly female customers.  She expects average monthly profits to reach 17,500 CFA francs, part of which will be used to pay off the loan and interests, while the rest will go into savings.  Her goal is to increase her turnover in order to better satisfy her customers.

loans.use: To buy oranges.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity is 38-year-old married woman with two children who attend school. She has had a business of selling charcoal in Yei, South Sudan, for three years. Charity is requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal for resale. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the school fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Maritza Elizabeth

texts.es:
La socia se sigue dedicando al negocio de tienda de abarrotes,ella vende arroz,azucar,leche,aceite entre otros productos,al socia trabaja desde las 7:00 a.m hasta las 8:00 p.m,por medio de este negocio la socia quiere salir adelante,el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes.La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar productos como arroz,azucar,leche y aceite al por mayor para implementar la tienda de abarrotes.

 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en: The member, Maritza Elizabeth, continues managing her grocery store business.  She sells rice, sugar, milk, oil, and other products.  She works from 7:00 am until 8:00 pm and wants to get ahead through this business.  Her dream is to expand her grocery store business.  She is requesting the loan to purchase wholesale rice, sugar, milk, and oil to stock her grocery store.  She is happy to be receiving the loan and promises to make her payments on time.

loans.use: to purchase wholesale products such as rice, sugar, milk, and oil to stock her grocery store.

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson is a 50-year-old married man. He has 3 children with ages ranging from 8 years to 17 years. He describes himself to be a self-motivated man. 

Johnson operates a poultry business where he sells chickens. He has been involved in this business for 2 years and employs 1 staff member. His business is located at a potential business area and his primary customers are hotels.  He describes his biggest business challenge to be high transportation cost used when delivering chickens to customers.  

Johnson will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy chickens to resell. His business goal is to buy more chicks within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he can buy an incubator .

loans.use: buy 200 chickens

loans.name: Darwin Wilfrido

texts.es: El cliente es de la ciudad de Quevedo.  Comenzó desde muy pequeño a trabajar en esta actividad, debido a que heredó el negocio de su padre.  Labora sembrando frutas a diario.  Es soltero y tiene 1 hijo.  Le gustaría poder incrementar su negocio a futuro.  Por ahora requiere el dinero del préstamo para la compra de fruta para su venta.
texts.en:
This borrower is from the city of Quevedo.  He started working in the business at a very young age when he took over this venture from his father.  He works by planting fruit on a daily basis.  

The borrower is single and has one child.  He would like to increase his business in the future, but for now he is requesting a loan so that he can buy fruit to sell.

loans.use: to buy fruit to sell.

loans.name: Aissatou's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe crée depuis le 09 Mai 2011 est constitué de 21 membres qui habitent tous dans le même village. Leur activité principale est le commerce.

Goundo se trouvant a droite de la photo, levant la bras,est notre emprunteuse vedette. Elle est mariée et mère de dix(10)enfants dont 03 filles et 07 garçons.

Avec son crédit,elle compte acheter des fruits et légumes d'une valeur de 30000f,des oignons a hauteur de 15000f et les 5000f qui restent pour son propre besoin.

Pour ces bénéfices,elle désire renforcer son épargne et participer aux charges familiales.
texts.en:
This group was set up on 9th May 2011 and is made up of 21 members who all live in the same village. Their main activity is trading.

Goundo, who is on the right of the photo with her arm raised, is our star borrower. She is married and mother to ten children: three girls and seven boys.

With her loan she is planning to buy fruit and vegetables to a value of 30,000 francs, onions to a value of 15,000 francs, and the remaining 5,000 francs will be used for her own needs.

She would like to boost her savings with the profits and also contribute to the family expenses.

loans.use: to buy goods (fruit, vegetables and onions).

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Lucy wants to buy packs of plates, spoons,3 tables and fruits

loans.name: Muattar

texts.en: The first loan Muattar received in May of 2003 was only $70. At that time she had only 2 years of experience in trade and was engaged in the sale of children's clothes at “Proletarsk” clothes market.  Her trading space consisted of 2 meters and the assortment of the goods included only the most necessary for successful trade. For getting more profit it was necessary to invest additional capital and that’s why she came to MicroInvest for a loan. Мuattar invested the total loan amount into an increasing the number and assortment of goods. At that time she did not use her profit for family expenses and invested it all back into her business. Her husband took care of her and their two children. She thinks that fact helped her to increase the volume of her business and to succeed. Recently she has approached the market administration about the increase of a trading place and now it is 4 meters.  She learned that trade of children’s shoes could be very profitable and could be a next step for development of her business. She will use her loan to buy various footwear for the spring and summer season.

loans.use: Retail trade of children clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing and reselling dry fish

loans.name: Tursunboy

texts.en: Tursunboy is 57 years and has 2 children. His son left to earn money for Russia and his wife with child live with Tursunboy. His son sends some money, but it is so few and that's why they live on Tursunboy's provision. Tursunboy's wife has invalid and is constantly ill. But, in spite of it Tursunboy and his wife regularly go to the market and trade. They have two trading points in the market. Profit from theur business is enough for life, also they both receive a pension, but not big. 1,5 years ago Tursunboy received his first loan and  significantly expanded his business. Gradually by getting new loans he expanded the assortment and quantity of goods. Now he wants to get next loan for the further expansion of his business.

loans.use: for the further expansion of his business

loans.name: Basheeran

texts.en: Last year I took out a loan with which I set up a grocery store and had three iron carts made. My family and I load the carts with fruit and vegetables and hire people on a daily-wage basis to manage the sales.  I, along with four of my children, run the grocery store. The income from these two ventures is just enough to meet the cost of living and send my youngest to school. I would like a loan of $300 to add more products to my grocery store and get two more carts made. That way our income will increase and we will be able to live better.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase animals

loans.name: Sayadpary

texts.en: Sayadpary (her son is pictured) is a mother of two children. She is 44 years old and lives in Khachmaz town. She and her son buy hides from the villages to make hats for sale. Now they need a loan of $1200 to buy the necessary materials for making the hats and so increase the number of their clients.

loans.use: To buy the necessary materials for making hats.

loans.name: Boboeva

texts.en: Boboeva B. lives in the town of Spitamen with her husband and four children.  She has been a MicroInvest client since 2006, and is a serious and highly-motivated businesswoman who has made very effective use of several loans. Mrs.Boboeva works in the local food bazaar, where she sells vegetable oil to a wide range of customers. She has applied for a loan of $900 to expand her business and increase her family's income.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Cielo Group

texts.es:
Cielo is the name of an association of 16 women who, a little more than one and a half years ago, joined Pro Mujer with the intention of improving their quality of life and developing certain business skills. Only in this form would they be able to face their obligations as mothers, and in some cases, head of the family. This association is characterized by the sale of food products and in some cases we can find the sale of electronics and clothing. Concerning food sales, the majority of the women possess stalls in the main markets, and in some cases, in the fairs of their zone. In the case of the other products, the women have to walk around in order sell and generate the necessary income for their families. Currently, the partners need capital in order to revive their businesses and take advantage of the festivities of Carnaval, when during the longer holiday, people tend to buy different products for the home or simply have parties when the food consumption is massive.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva volunteer.

Cielo, es el nombre de la asociación comunal que reúne a 16 mujeres que hace poco mas de un año y medio ingresaron a Pro Mujer con la intención de mejorar su calidad de vida, y principalmente de desarrollar ciertas destrezas en los negocios, solo de esta forma podrían hacer frente a las obligaciones que representa ser madre y en algunos casos jefa de familia. Esta asociación se caracteriza por la venta de productos alimenticios, y en algunos casos podemos encontrar la venta de artefactos electrónicos y prendas de vestir. En lo que respecta a la venta de productos alimenticios, la mayoría posee puestos propios en los principales mercados y en algunos casos en las ferias de la zona. En referencia a los otros productos, diremos que deben deambular para poder vender y generar las ganancias necesarias para sus familias. Actualmente las socias precisan de capital para poder reactivar sus negocios con el fin de aprovechar los festejos de las fiestas de carnaval, donde lo extenso del feriado, la gente tiende a abastecerse de distintos productos del hogar, o simplemente realiza fiestas y prestes donde el consumo de alimentos también es masivo.

loans.use: The partners need capital to revive their businessesesfor the Carnaval festivities.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet A. is married to a pastor and has 4 children.  Janet sells second hand clothing in a small fishing village just outside of Cape Coast called Elmina.  She is requesting a loan of $475 to buy additional clothing so she can expand her business.  She hopes this loan will increase her profits and she’ll be able to provide additional income to her family.

Janet is also a member of a lending group called “Nkor Ma Ahoto Traders”, which consists of 11 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To buy additional clothing so she can expand her business.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita considers herself to be an honest person, hard-working with a strong desire to get ahead. She started the business because she needed an income and also because she likes pastries and sales. Plus it's something that she learned many years ago because her family is in the same business. She began making and selling bread 20 years ago when her family had a long-established bakery, a business they closed two years ago due to her father's advancing years. He could no longer work and it was then that she decided to make bread and sell it from home, something that she liked doing. Her business is now going strong and she has a lot of customers.

Margarita is applying for a US$300 loan, to be repaid in 3 months, to buy basic ingredients, containers and baking tins so that she can make more and increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Margarita D. se considera una persona honesta, trabajadora y con muchas ganas de salir adelante; inicio el negocio por la necesidad de tener un ingreso además de que le gusta la repostería y las ventas, ya que es una actividad que aprendió hace muchos años porque su familia se dedicaba a eso. Comenzó a elaborar y vender pan hace 20 años, en aquel entonces su familia tenía una panadería establecida la cual cerraron hace dos años por la avanzada edad de su papá que ya no podía trabajar y fue cuando decido elaborar el pan en casa y venderlo a domicilio, lo cual le agrada hacer y en la actualidad le ha ido muy bien y tiene muchos clientes

Solicita un crédito por US $300 que pagara en 3 meses para adquirir materia prima, recipientes y moldes que le permitan elaborar más y de esta manera puedo incrementar mis ventas.

loans.use: Buy basic supplies for bakery business.

loans.name: Pastor

texts.en:
Pastor P. has been dedicated to the business of cattle ranching for the last 16 years in the municipality of Villanueva in Chinandega. This business requires a lot of dedication for the fact that is demands a lot of effort to carry out the breeding. This is also true due to the fact that it requires the strict control of every one of the animals and at the same time feed and care for those that are older.

It is necessary to emphasize through this business Mr. P. is able to maintain his spouse and son. It is because of this he his soliciting a loan through Ceprodel . The credit will allow him to be the animals, which he will turn around and sell to the Villanueva community.

Translated from Spanish by James Lombardo, Kiva volunteer

El caballero Pastor P. se dedica al negocio de la ganadería desde hace 16 años en el municipio de Villanueva de la ciudad de Chinandega. Este negocio requiere de mucha dedicación por el hecho de que se necesita de mucho esfuerzo para llevar a cabo la crianza de ganado debido a que se debe de tener un estricto control de cada uno de los animales y a su vez alimentar de la manera mas adecuada.

Es necesario destacar que por medio de este negocio, el señor P. logra mantener a su cónyuge y su hijo en edad escolar. Es por este motivo que hoy en día busca apoyo en Ceprodel para obtener créditos que le permitan la compra de los animales (terneros) para su respectiva comercialización en la comunidad de Villanueva.

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Rohila

texts.en: Rohila A. lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. Like many of her fellow villagers she is engaged in the livestock business. It is the family business but she has her own duties. Mrs. A. is responsible for taking care of the animals and for milk production and making sour products. It is a very hard work. Mrs. A. is married and has a child. Besides this she works on a collective farm. She works hard and has a good reputation. Now Mrs. A. is applying with KIVA for help with a business development loan of 2600 STJ for 8 months. She'd like to purchase special modernized equipment to process milk to make milk-sour products.

loans.use: Rohila would like to purchase special modernized equipment to process milk to make milk-sour products.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina is an experienced trader in Koforidua market, Ghana. She is thirty one years old, married, and has two children. Her husband is pictured in her place because she was not available. Faustina has been selling hair products for the past eight years. The major product she currently trades in is weave-ons. ‘Doing good business requires good working capital’, she said. She wants to expand her shop to include additional types of weave-ons, hair creams, shampoo, and activators to make her store a one-stop shop for her customers. This is her dream, and it is because of this that she wants to pursue a loan. Faustina is a group member of the Blood of Jesus Trust Group. Members of this group help support one another in successfully paying back loans on time, and Faustina feels she is capable of repaying her loan as her business grows.

loans.use: To buy assorted weavons and hair creams, shampoo and activators.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel I. is 49 years old and married with 3 children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She sells provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs.  She has been in this business since 2003.  She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy more drinks, provisions, and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, provisions, and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Olmagul

texts.en:
Olmagul S. is 34 years old and comes from a large and humble family. She is married and the loving mother of 2 children. Her father's hard and demanding character showed her, from the time she was a little girl, the significant value of work, and therefore she has been successful in various activities throughout her life.

Now Olmagul is dedicating herself to raising and selling cattle and with the income she generates, she provides a better quality of life for her children, who are her greatest joy and have become her best friends. She is asking for a 2000 Somoni (600 USD) loan with a term of 12 months in order to buy more young cattle to later sell when they are fully grown. With this investment she will be able to substantially grow her earnings and improve her quality of life. Let’s support this dedicated mother's proposal.

loans.use: Purchasing young cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Dinara

texts.en: Dinara (her father is pictured) was born in 1985. She lives in Baku city. Her father has been in the construction business for 10 years. Now they need a loan of $1200 to buy the necessary things like tools for improving their business.

loans.use: to buy tools and necessary things to improve their business

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in a historic place named Yadgar, in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house, where she has been living for 16 years. She is the mother of five children: four daughters and one son. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. For 10 years, Yasmeen baji’s husband has had a business selling vegetables. Yasmeen baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family.

Yasmeen baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah. She requests a loan to buy more vegetables to resell. Her loan group includes two other members. Rubina baji requests a loan to pay installments of her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Shahnaz baji requests a loan to purchase leather for her shoe-making business.

loans.use: Buy more vegetables to resell

loans.name: Fabiola Del Socorro

texts.es: la Sra. Fabiola  tiene 35 años de edad, casada y con tres hijos de 12,14,17 años de edad,  los cuales los tres estudian, su esposo es miembro de la policía nacional de Nicaragua, el negocio de doña Fabiola  es en  ventas de ropa, zapatos y cosméticos algunos por encargos y siempre tiene mercadería, sus ventas son al crédito y al contado, ella inicio desde hace 20 años lo cual ha logrado mucha experiencia en las ventas ya que su madre vendía ropa y viajaba a honduras a comprar lo cual obtenía muchas ganancias, por la falta de financiamiento para la inversión y la inestabilidad política y económica de nuestro país enfrenta, eso ha impedido su desarrollo para crecer en su negocio, con esta solicitud es la segunda en Afodenic la cual va invertir en inventario de ropa y zapatos en bastante variedad para la temporada. A largo plazo es poder obtener más financiamiento que le permita capitalizarse y llegar a nuevos segmentos.
texts.en:
Fabiola is 35 years old, married and has three children of ages 12, 14 and 17, respectively, whom are students. Her husband is a member of the national police of Nicaragua. Fabiola's business is the selling of clothing, shoes and cosmetics, some by order but she always has merchandise and her sales are on credit and in cash. She started twenty years ago which has provided a lot experience in retail, especially since her mother sold clothing and traveled to Honduras to purchase it, which provided lots of profit. The lack of available financing for investment and the political and economic instability that Nicaragua faces has impeded ability to grow the business. With this loan, which would be her second from Afodenic, she will invest in inventory for her clothing and shoes, in sufficient variety from the season. In the long term she would like to obtain more financing that would allow her reach new market segments.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a variety of clothing and shoes for the upcoming season

loans.name: Jaber

texts.en:
Jaber is a 32-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. He has been working as a car painter since 2005. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise and tools for his business. This is the first time that Jaber has requested a loan.

Jaber is special in his work because he is honest with his clients. His clients are friends and neighbors. He decided to open his own business because of his experience and professionalism. In the future, he plans to expand his business and to sustain it.

loans.use: Jaber needs the loan to purchase merchandise and tools for his business.

loans.name: Yasser

texts.en: Yasser is a 39-year-old married man with two children He lives in Jib Jennine in the Bekaa valley. Yasser has a mini-market in his village where he serves his community. Over the years, he has been able to attract a growing number of clients. Yasser is requesting a loan of $1000 to buy more goods.

loans.use: Buy goods

loans.name: María

texts.es:
La señora Maria es socia del Banco Comunal “Las estrellitas Unidas del Titicaca”, del centro poblado de Chipana, distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno; de 33 años de edad, tiene dos hijos, es viuda y posee estudios de primaria incompleta (quinto de primaria).
Trabaja hace un año con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos ella se dedica a la crianza de cerdos y primer préstamo fue de S/.300.00 nuevos soles y se siente contenta porque le permitió comprar lechones para engordarlo y luego venderlo.
Con este préstamo de S/. 1100.0 nuevos soles, monto que destinará a compra de  ganado vacuno y ternero para poder engordarlos y venderlos en las ferias ganaderas de Pilcuyo, Ilave; ella de esta manera contribuirá a mejorar la calidad educativa de sus hijos; asimismo se compromete a pagar puntualmente su préstamo sus cinco cuotas mensuales.
texts.en:
Señora Maria is a member of the community bank "Las estrellitas Unidas del Titicaca”, in Chipana, district of Pilcuyo, Province of El Collao, Department of Puno. She is 33 years of age, has two children, is a widow, and has a 5th grade education.

She has worked for a year with the Manuela Ramos Movement and raises pigs. Her first loan of S/ 300.00 nuevos soles made her happy becuase it allowed her to buy piglets to fatten and to later sell.

With this loan of S/ 1100.0 nuevos soles ($350), she will buy cattle and calves to be able to fatten and sell them in the livestock fairs in Pilcuyo, Ilave. In this way she will contribute to bettering the quality of her children's education. Also, she commits to punctually pay back her loan in 5 monthly payments.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cattle and calves to be able to fatten them and sell them in the livestock fairs in Pilcuyo, Ilave; she, in this way, will contribute to better quality education for her children.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Mrs. Brenda F. was born in Hamtic, Antique, Philippines. She is 26 years old, married, and blessed with 2 children. She is engaged in hog-raising, Natasha Dealing (representing a direct sales company selling shoes etc.), and Tricycad Service (3-wheeled bicycle used for transport). These have been their businesses since the first year of her membership in ASHI.

The initial capital she used in starting up the businesses was P 5,000 only. She received her loan on February 10, 2009 amounting to P 23,000 as additional capital for Natasha Dealing, purchasing piglets and repairing of her tricycad.

Ms. F. dreams that she might have a tricycad repair shop and other shop-related projects so that she would have sources of capital for sending her children to school and to attain a higher level of education. She would like to thank Kiva lenders who will sponsor her loan.

loans.use: Tricycad, hog raising, Natasha Dealing

loans.name: Solijon

texts.en:
Committed to his family and his business, U. Solijon, works very hard at ranching. His has his own herd of cattle and works in the field every day to earn a living to support his dear wife and two children. As every business requires investment, Solijon needs some young bulls, which will be raised and sold. For this reason, he turns to IMON International again, to obtain a loan which will allow him to acquire cattle and help him improve the standard of living for his beloved family. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, including a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets-Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities still speaking the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization dating back to the 4th millennium BC.  Today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R and further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing young cattle to raise and sell

loans.name: Maria De Jesus

texts.es:
Maria de Jesus inició el negocio porqué siempre le gustaron las ventas y desde muy joven se dedico al comercio y gracias a ello ha podido junto con su esposo sacar adelante a sus hijos.
Comenzó el negocio En Marzo de 2002 vendiendo taquitos en la parte de enfrente de su casa y luego acondiciono un lugar en las esquina de su casa donde se pude instalar mejor acomodando algunas mesas y sillas para que sus clientes pudieran estar mas cómodos. A partir de julio de 2005 comenzo a elaborar banquetes para todo tipo de fiestas. 

Desde que inicio le ha ido muy bien y en la actualidad cuenta con bastante mobiliario como loza y mantelería, cubre-manteles en 8 tonos diferentes, para los gustos de sus clientes y además acaba de adquirir un equipo de sonido para un servicio más completo a sus clientes.

Ella necesita un prestamo por MXN $12,000 para comprar materia prima y elaborar sus banquetes y algo de mantelería para ir supliendo los manteles que se van deteriorando con el uso.
texts.en:
Maria de Jesus began the business because she always liked selling and from very young she dedicated herself to it. Thanks to the business she has been able to, along with her husband, push her children forward. In March 2002 she began selling taquitos in the front part of her house and soon she arranged a place in the corner of her house where she could install better accommodations, some tables and chairs, so that her customers would be more comfortable. As of July 2005 she began to elaborate banquets for all type of celebrations. Ever since she began the business, it has gone very well for her and currently she relies on enough household goods like plates, table linens, and table cloths in 8 different tones, for her customers’ tastes. In addition, she has just finished acquiring sound equipment for a more complete service. She is requesting a loan to buy raw materials, to elaborate her banquets, and to replace some table linens that have deteriorated with use.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Reynolds, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Stahil Salama Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 26 years old, married, and has a two-year-old child. She has been a clothes seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Stahil Salama Group loan (Group code 2026). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $60. She works hard at her business everyday. 

Fatma requests her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more clothes for resale to improve her business. She hopes that through the loan her profit will increase, and she will be able to grow her business. 

She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Chakacha, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale to expand her business.

loans.name: Houssein

texts.en: Houssein is a 27-year-old man who lives in Tyre in southern Lebanon. Houssein has been working as a blacksmith for 12 years. He requested a loan of $1,000 from Al Majmoua to purchase electrical wires for his work and repaid that on time. This is his third loan; he has always paid on time. Houssein started his business because he wanted to work independently, and the business quickly became successful. In the future, he plans on improving his business and honing his skills.

loans.use: Purchase of electrical wire

loans.name: Arthuro

texts.en:
Arthuro is 41 years old and married to Virginia who is 37 years old. They help each other in maintaining their family’s standard of living, and they work hard to give their children a better future. Virginia manages a village store, and Arthur is a rice farmer. Sadly, Arthuro shared that his eldest child died because of a gunshot wound. He said it was the most tragic event that has ever happened to his family. Their youngest child, Gerald, is now nine years old and is studying in elementary school. Arthuro hopes to give him a good education so that he may have a successful future.

Arthuro is requesting a loan of PHP 16,000 for his farming business. He hopes to expand his business with the help of the loan. His family lives in the village of St. Tomas in Alicia, Isabela where farming is the main source of income for most of the populace. Arthuro says that their village has an irrigated area, and they have enough water for all of their crops.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Atinuke

texts.en: Atinuke is a member of LAPO and she sells drinks and foodstuffs. She needs a loan of N50,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell; she said this will increase her profit and help her serve her customers better. Atinuke is 45 years old, widowed and has three children. With her business, she provides for the needs of her children as she has no support from anyone. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Mangwi

texts.en:
Mangwi G. was born in 1966 and is the mother of one child. G. originally joined GHAPE and got her first empowerment credit in 2008 and since that time, she and her husband have enjoyed the benefit of GHAPE empowerment credits. With her first loan, she invested in farming and has used the profits of her products to invest in her child and family, paying for her brothers' and sisters' school fees and for their medications.
Throughout the years, G. has suffered the consequences of poor health, and the death of her husband. Besides that, G. and her family have simply suffered the results of poverty and the accompanying challenges that life has brought them.
 She has years of experience in her business, which has helped her in having sound business policies. 
With her second GHAPE loan, she intends to invest in expanding her business. With the profits of this business, she will be able to afford the school fees of her other children, and will be able to continue providing good healthful medications for them. She will be able to feed her family, provide them with clothes and will have the opportunity to save for the future as well. 
G. came to GHAPE because of the training scheme the organization offers, because of the terms of the loans, and because the method of repayment is “comfortable and convenient”.
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase yams, corn, and beans

loans.name: Abdumanon

texts.ru: Нарзуллоев Абдуманон проживает в районе Явана. Возраст 57 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Абдуманон более 25 лет работает по специальности, "преподавателем". В данный момент занимается животноводством. Он более 5 лет откармливает и продает скот. Кредит просит для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Abdumanon N. lives in the Yavan district. He is 57 years old, married and has 6 children. Abdumanon has been working as a teacher for over 25 years. Currently, he is also involved in animal husbandry. He has been feeding and selling livestock for over 5 years. He is requesting a loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda is known as a woman who is full of fighting spirit and strong determination. For her, as she puts it, “Poverty is not a hindrance in achieving one's dream in life. Just work diligently and face all the trials that will come along." She adds, "Don’t let anyone or anything bring you down." Merlinda dreams of giving her children a complete education despite their difficulties in life. She says that she will do everything she can for the sake of attaining their dreams for her children.

Merlinda is engaged in a retail business: specifically, a general store. She also raises livestock. To allow for a continuous business growth, she is requesting a loan in the amount of PHP 7,000, which will to be used for the maintenance of her businesses. She plans to purchase food, supplies, and additional goods for the store.

Merlinda is 41 years old and married to Rodolfo, a Jeep transport driver. The couple have six children, five of whom are in school. Her youngest is just a year old. She hopes that through her patience and diligence, she will be able to fulfill her dreams of expanding her business to sustain the needs of her children.

loans.use: To purchase food, supplies, and additional goods for the store.

loans.name: Nuevo Renacer 1, 3, 4 Group

texts.en:
Eneroliza is a warm-hearted mother of four running a small roadside bakery and ice cream store from her house.  She is a self-taught baker. Over eight years ago, she decided to start selling bread and had only a limited idea of how to make it.  Over the years, she slowly learned how to properly mix and bake her ingredients, including flour, yeast, sugar and coconut oil.  Now, Eneroliza finds business brisk as people from all over come to her house to purchase from her household bakery.  She has found business to be successful enough to be currently taking out her fifth loan with Esperanza.

Living with her husband and four children ages 24, 19, 15 and 13, she is grateful for the ability to supplement her husband’s income and provide more food for the family.  She is also hoping to provide her children with the opportunity to attend a university – her only daughter would love to study engineering, and her sons are considering studying law.

Beyond supporting her children’s future, Eneroliza dreams about owning her own beauty salon. She has been taking classes with the hopes of opening up her own location in the future, using the profits from her bread and ice cream sales today.  Extra funds from either business would go to improving her home which currently lacks a bathroom and other facilities.

Thank you for supporting this Kiva loan!

loans.use: To buy flour, yeast, coconut oil and ice cream supplies

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie A. is a 30-year-old woman from the village of Del Carmen, Iligan City. Rosemarie is married and has an infant-aged child. To make a living, Rosemarie owns and operates a business in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Her main source of business income comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years, and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

Rosemarie joined HSPFI in 2009 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation, and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be Rosemarie's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from new products to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase new inventory

loans.name: Elham

texts.en: Elham is a 56-year-old married woman. She has owned a clothes shop since 2007 to provide, along with her children, better life conditions. Today, Elham is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy more merchandise so she can increase her sales and therefore her income.

loans.use: buy more merchandise

loans.name: La Nueva Union 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Germania is the group coordinator of her group, La Nueva Union (the New Union), and her story is representative of both the members of her group and also of Esepranza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whome recently emigrated from the DR to Haiti) clients. Her group is based in the areas surrounding La Romana, an area where the economy is based on the sugarcane industry and where there is little access to running water (none of which is potable) or stable electricity. Here she makes her home with her two children and husband.

Germania has proven herself to be an excellent client of Esperanza and she has successfully repaid three loans already. With this new loan, she will purchase clothing in bulk to sell and bed coverings. She has identified a market for these goods among her neighbors and she believes the increased profits will allow her to buy school supplies for her kids and continue to increase her business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy bed coverings and clothing to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy wood

loans.name: Family United Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Family United Group. They are small-scale businesspeople in the township of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT for the first time to seek a loan of Le 2,500,000 (or Le 500,000 for each) to boost their businesses. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make better profit and consequently improve their living standard. 

Fatmata S. (second from left) is the leader of this group. She was born in Magburaka town. She is 42 and a widow with three children. Fatmata has been a businesswoman for more than 15 years now. Fatmata buys snails from Magburaka and sells in Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. And in Monrovia, she buys items like biscuits and mayonnaise and sells in Sierra Leone. She will use this loan to buy bags of snails to sell in Liberia.

loans.use: Buy snails to sell in Liberia

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is 35 years old and is married with four children. He lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria.

Samson makes and sells cellophane (a thin, transparent sheet used for food packaging), a business that is now booming. With the loan of N50,000 he plans to expand his cellophane business by buying more material for the production of cellophane.

With this kind of business Samson hopes to increase his earnings in the long run and be able to better provide for his children's education. He says a big thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more material for the production of cellophane

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Nov S., 44, is a married mother of three children. She and her husband have established their own household in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. To generate a daily income, Nov S. receives small pieces of cloth from the garment industry and prepares them as sets for fees. She normally earns around $4 each day to contribute to her family’s living expenses. Her husband is shown near her in the picture above. He helps provide for the family by providing a taxi service. Recently, Nov S.’s husband has needed a trailer to connect to his existing motorcycle, which will allow him to pick up more customers than he previously could. Nov S. requested a loan of $600 to be used to buy a trailer.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle trailer

loans.name: Union Collana Group

texts.es:
UNION COLLANA

En esta alcancía participan once personas microempresarias la mayoría de ellos son agricultores, a través de sus negocios consiguen el sustento en sus hogares, darle lo mejor a los suyos es uno de sus muchos objetivos. Así pues conoceremos el testimonio de Adrían quien es el tesorero del grupo más de dos años y medio. 
Es agricultor desde hace más de diez años, sus padres le cedieron una tierras lo cual aprovecha en sembrar alfalfa es lo que más produce y obtiene mayor rentabilidad porque se cosecha hasta seis veces al año. Como todo padre quiere darles lo mejor a sus dos hijos de 11 y 6 años adicionó en cultivar frutas como manzana, membrillo y algunos tubérculos como choclo, arvejas, espinaca, papa. Para ello necesitó del préstamo para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, pesticidas, abono foliares, herbecidas. Los productos son vendidos a los compradores del mercado mayoristas. 
De esta manera Adrián comparte los gastos con su esposa en educar a sus niños, vestimenta, alimentación, así mismo llegó a adquirir algunos electrodomésticos que antes no tenían de las ganancias de sus ventas como televisor, DVD, equipo de sonido. Hubo un momento que debido a los inesperados desastres naturales provocó un huayco en la zona que dificultó el transito por tres día a los camiones (compradores mayoristas) teniendo que rematar la mercadería de tubérculos a fin de recuperar algo de la inversión. El crédito que necesita es para comprar la semilla, abono, hacer instalaciones de alfalfa, contratar a peones para el arado y riego de la tierra. Trabajar así permite no faltar en la economía para su hogar.
texts.en:
UNION COLLANA This communal bank is made up of eleven micro-entrepreneurs, most of whom are farmers. The members manage to support their families through their businesses, and one of their many goals is to provide the best for their families. Let’s hear the testimony of Adrían, who has been the group’s treasurer for more than two-and-a-half years. He has been a farmer for over ten years. His parents gave him some land that he uses to plant alfalfa—this is the crop that he produces the most and gets the most return from, since it is harvested six times a year. Like all parents, he wants to provide the best for his two children, aged 11 and 6 years old. He also grows fruits such as apples and quinces along with other crops that include corn, peas, spinach, and potatoes. He needed a loan in order to purchase seeds, fertilizer, pesticides, and herbicides. He sells his produce to wholesale buyers from the market. Adrían and his wife share the expenses of educating their children and providing them with clothes and food. They have even purchased some electrical appliances that they didn’t have before when they didn’t earn profits from their sales, such as a TV, a DVD player, and audio equipment. There was a period when the region was hit by unexpected natural disasters in the wake of a flash flood, which made transport difficult—the journey (for the wholesale buyers) took three days by truck—and Adrían had to sell off his produce to make up for some of the investment. The loan that he needs now is for purchasing seeds and fertilizer for planting alfalfa, and hiring farm workers to plow and irrigate the land. Working thus allows him to earn money for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer for planting alfalfa

loans.name: Hadi

texts.en: Hadi is an 18-year-old single man. In 2007, this young man decided to work as a builder and begin a new career. He learned this occupation from his two brothers. Today, Hadi is requesting a loan of $500 to buy a tractor, because this talented man is planning to enlarge and expand his business by taking more and bigger projects.

loans.use: to buy a tractor

loans.name: Peterson

texts.en:
Peterson is 28 years old and married with a one-year-old child. He is a farmer in the Nyamira area of Western Kenya. He's been farming for three years and already employs six people. He sells milk, tea, and cereals locally. He also earns income from selling clothes. He says that the main challenges to growing his business are poor market conditions, lack of financing, and diseases that strike his livestock.

He requested this loan through the Kiva field partner, Juhudi Kilimo, for 60,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 45,000 KES.  He says this new loan will help him better provide for his family's needs because of the increased milk production. In the future, he'd like to produce at least 50 litres each day.

About Juhudi Kilimo
Juhudi Kilimo is an innovative, for-profit social enterprise working with smallholder farmers in Kenya. Juhudi directly finances dairy cows, chickens, agricultural equipment and other assets that are specifically chosen to create immediate cash flow. Many of the assets are insured to prevent devastating business losses, and targeted technical assistance is provided to farmers, from agricultural training to basic bookkeeping and local market research. For its clients and their families, Juhudi also offers life insurance and a medical aid program. Through all these services, Juhudi is creating sustainable growth and employment in rural communities across Kenya.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen, de 36 años, vive en su casa propia al lado de su esposo Gregorio (36), quien es obrero de una mina, y de sus 4 hijas: Rosario (16), Yazmín (14), Xiomara (8) y Rubí (5).

Desde muy joven aprendió las técnicas del tejido, porque su madre le inculcó este arte, y desde entonces no ha parado de tejer. En la actualidad elabora todo tipo de prendas y tapetes y se ha dado cuenta que es un negocio muy rentable; además es un oficio que le gusta mucho porque la relaja y es tranquilo, pues lo desarrolla en la tranquilidad de su casa. 
Paralelamente a esta actividad, desde hace un año, se dedica a la preparación y venta de desayunos y almuerzos, los que reparte a sus habituales comensales, trabajadores de la zona por donde vive, quienes le pagan mensualmente. Siendo una mujer muy emprendedora, para el futuro tiene planeado instalar un pequeño restaurante donde pueda ofrecer sus comidas con mayor tranquilidad.

Este es el primer préstamo que tiene con MFP y está muy agradecida con todas aquellas personas que hacen posible la obtención de su crédito para su progreso. Con el dinero que solicita comprará lana e hilo para continuar tejiendo, ya que tiene varios pedidos por entregar y no quiere quedar mal con sus clientes.
texts.en:
Carmen, 36, lives in her own house with her husband, Gregorio, 36, who works in a mine, and their four daughters: Rosario, 16, Yazmín, 14, Xiomara, 8 and Rubí, 5. She learned to weave as a little girl because her mother taught her this art; since then, she hasn't stopped weaving. Currently, she makes all kinds of clothing articles and rugs and she has noted that it is a very profitable business. Besides, it is an occupation that she enjoys very much because it's calm and it relaxes her; she can do it from the comfort of her home. In addition to this activity, for the past year she has sold prepared breakfasts and lunches to her regular diners who are, for the most part, local laborers; they pay her on a monthly basis. Being a very enterprising woman, she is planning to set up a small restaurant in the future where she can offer her meals with more tranquility. This is her first loan with MFP. She is very grateful to all those people who make getting credit possible for her progress. With the requested funds she will buy wool and thread to continue weaving since she has several orders pending and she does not want to disappoint her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wool and thread.

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en:
Kemi is very happy with the growth of her business; with her last Kiva loan she bought more bags of flour and other baking items in large quantities. She makes snacks like egg rolls, fish rolls, meat pie and more. She has been able to produce snacks in large quantity, thereby satisfying the demands of her customers.

She hopes for a loan of NGN 160,000 to purchase more bags of flour and yeast to make more snacks to sell.

47 years old Kemi is married with 2 children. She assists her husband in paying for her children’s education and hopes to see them graduate in the future. She thanks Kiva and LAPO microfinance for this wonderful initiative.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of flour to make more snacks to sell.

loans.name: Karla

texts.es: La Sra. Karla Fabiola E. es profesora de secundaria tiene 24 años de ser maestra, es casada tiene dos niños menores en edad escolar, el dinero lo solicita para la terminación de su casa va a comprar materiales de construcción como cerámica, cemento, pago del transporte del traslado del material y pago de la mano de obra, y todos los créditos que ha tenido con ceprodel los ha invertido en la construcción de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Karla Fabiola E. has been a junior high school teacher for 24 years. She's married and has two small school age children. She is requesting this money to finish her home. She will purchase construction materials such as ceramic tile and cement, and will pay for the transportation of the materials as well as for the labour. All the loans she has had from Ceprodel have been invested in the construction of her home.

Translated from Spanish by Nadine Riopel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cement and blocks

loans.name: Wilfrido

texts.es:
Wilfrido E. O.  tiene 63 años y vive en San Juan Nepomuceno Municipio del Departamento de  Bolívar,  con su cónyuge y su hijo de 7 años. Él se dedica a la reparación y ensamble de baterías,  actividad que aprendió hace 20 años en el municipio El Difícil en el municipio del Magdalena con un sobrino. Anteriormente trabajaba en Cartagena pero sufrió un accidente de transito, que lo obligó a dejar de trabajar y por esto se quedó sin recursos, pero al aprender este oficio monto su negocio   y  de él depende su familia junto a una pensión que tiene. Para el desarrollo de este negocio Wilfrido  compra baterías viejas, las desarma y luego las arregla y las vende;  también compra las partes y las arma.  El ha recibido varios créditos con la fundación en el programa de grupos solidarios y este es su primer crédito individual y solicita un valor de $2.000.000, para invertirlo  en la  compra de  placas, separadores y cajas para batería. Su sueño es mejorar locativamente su taller e independizarlo pues funciona en su casa  y quiere repellar las paredes y instalar pisos nuevos pero sobretodo seguir reciclando baterías  viejas para el uso muchos mas vehículos que amplíen su mercado de trabajo.

El desafió mas grande que ha tenido y que lo marcó significativamente,  fue cuando por el accidente dejó de trabajar  por un tiempo y los recursos que le quedaron  de sus ahorros se los gastó,   pero hoy con su pensión ha logrado salir adelante  porque con ella pudo  montar su negocio.
texts.en:
Wilfrido E. O., 63, lives in San Juan Nepomuceno, Bolívar department, with his wife and 7-year-old son. He repairs and rebuilds batteries, a skill he learned 20 years ago with his nephew in the town of El Difícil, Magdalena. He used to work in Cartagena but a traffic accident forced him to stop working and left him without resources. However, having learned this skill, he set up his business which, together with a small pension he receives, supports his family. Wilfrido buys old batteries, takes them apart, refurbishes them, and resells them. He also buys battery parts and builds them from scratch. He has gotten several past loans from the foundation through communal banks but this will be his first individual loan. He is asking for $2.000.000 to buy plates, insulators and battery casings. His dream is to improve his workshop’s location since it is currently in his home and he wants to seal the walls and install new flooring. Above all, he wants to continue to recycle old batteries for use in many more vehicles so that his market will grow. His greatest challenge, which had a huge impact on him, was when the accident forced him to stop working and he spent all his savings. Today, thanks to his pension, he has managed to move forward because it made it possible for him to set up his business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy battery parts.

loans.name: Abed El Latif

texts.en:
Abed El Latif is a 22 year old single man. He works on a freelance basis as a home painter. He learned the business at the age of 18 at a previous job. He works hard to satisfy the demands of his job, in order to pay his daily expenses and provide a better living for his family. Due to his good work, and because he is a hard-working man, he has gained lots of clients and enlarged his network.

This is the first time that he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase paint and tools for his work. He hopes that this loan will allow him to purchase new and better tools to improve his work.

loans.use: To purchase paint and tools for his work.

loans.name: Ahemaa Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Louis is forty-five years old. He is married and has four children who are between the ages of six and eighteen. All are currently in school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in their community. His wife is a farmer who cultivates food crops to support the family.

Louis is a hard-working man. He is the proprietor of a private school in the community. His school being one of the good ones in town has made many parents enroll their offspring there. He has been in business for ten years. 

Louis wants the loan to enable him to have his broken-down school bus mended and also to procure other logistics to facilitate teaching and learning. He hopes to give his children the best education he can afford. 

Louis is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Ahenema’, which literally means 'royals'. The group is made up of thirteen members. Some are petty traders and others are into food production/sales. The group requests the loan to procure goods and raw materials in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: Repair broken-down school bus

loans.name: Alamiro

texts.es:
Alamiro tiene 33 años de edad, es casado, y vive junto a su esposa y sus cuatro hijos en el caserío El Progreso, un sector rural dedicado exclusivamente a la agricultura y a la ganadería, pertenece al distrito de Lagunas y se encuentra  ubicado a cuarenta y cinco minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Hace mas de dos años que se dedica a la ganadería, posee cuatro vacas lecheras que cría con mucho esfuerzo, ya que son la única fuente de ingreso económico diario de su familia; la leche producida por sus animales la vende diariamente a una empresa acopiadora de la zona, que le compra el producto a 0,90 nuevos soles el litro.

Alamiro desea comprar alimento balanceado para mejorar la producción de su ganado lechero y así percibir mayores ingresos, además planea brindar mantenimiento a un cultivo de maíz chala que planea utilizar en la alimentación de su ganado. Para lograr su meta ha solicitado a Edpyme Altenativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles.

Alamiro es una persona que gusta mucho de las labores que realiza por lo que siempre trata de realizarlas de la mejor manera. Su mayor anhelo es construir una casa de material noble, ya que la que tiene es de adobe y no les ofrece la seguridad necesaria.

Alamiro ya había trabajado anteriormente con el fondo Kiva y se encuentra agradecido porque gracias a la ayuda brindada pudo completar el dinero que necesitaba para adquirir una de las vacas que actualmente posee.
texts.en:
Alamiro is 33 years old, married and lives with his wife and their four children in their farmhouse, El Progreso, a rural sector dedicated to agriculture and livestock in the district of Lagunas that is located forty five minutes from the city of Chiclayo.

For more than two years, he has raised stock. He has four milking cows that he raised with much effort, and now they are the only source of daily income for his family. The milk that his animals produce is sold daily to a local wholesale business, that purchases the products for 0,90 PEN a liter ($.030 USD).

Alamiro wants to purchase a balanced food to improve the production of his dairy farm, and in this way receive a better profit. Also, he plans to maintain a cultivation of corn that he can to use to feed his farm. To achieve his goal, he has asked Edpyme Altenativa for a loan of 1500 PEN ($525 USD).

Almiro is a person who really enjoys his work and always tries to find a better way to do things. His biggest dream is to construct a home of quality materials, since the one he has is made of adobe and doesn’t offer the necessary security.

Alamiro has already worked with Kiva and is grateful because thanks to the support offered, he was able to put together the money to acquire one of the cows that he now owns.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a balanced food and improve the production of his farm

loans.name: Touch's Group

texts.en: This group loan is made up of four people who are located in Pun Phnum village in Takeo province. All of these group members will use a portion of their loan for different purposes to improve their businesses. The other members have selected Mrs. Touch Y. is a group leader. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she can grow rice to sell to support her family. She is widow with three children all attending a local public school. However, she tries to work with her field she only gets a small amount of rice. So to improve her family's costs of living, Mrs. Touch Y. is asking for a loan to buy some piglets to breed, to start a new business. She hopes that she can earn more money than previously, using this loan.

loans.use: To buy some piglets to breed.

loans.name: Banco Cartagena Group

texts.en:
There are 21 members of the "Cartagena" communal bank, and they live in Cartagena, a coastal community from the 5th Region in Chile.  Their businesses are: the preparation and sale of foods like bread, empanadas, sweets, and salads (among others); kiosks and hardware shops; door-to-door clothing sales; and fishing.

Julia is the secretary of the communal bank, in the attached picture you see her in the center, with a beige zip-up fleece and sort hair, making bunny ears over the head of one of the other group members.  For ten years Julia has been preparing breads, empanadas, and "berlines" (round pastries with cream filling) in her home, and selling the products from her home to neighbors, friends, and other clients she has met.  The best times for sales are over holidays and long weekends, when people arrive to enjoy the beach in Cartagena.

Julia has the support of her husband, who is a bread maker.  They have five grown children, who live independently with families of their own.

With the Fondo Esperanza loan, Julia will purchase ingredients and is considering the possibility of also purchasing a large mechanical bread mixer, which will help her make the dough for her products.  Her husband can help her in the purchase of the machine, because the cost is pretty high.
Julia's dream is to have a bread shop in Cartagena where she, her husband, and two of her sons can work; one of them is also a bread maker and the other makes pastries.

Of the work she has done with Fondo Esperanza, Julia notes that the promotion of the value of the interpersonal relationship between the members of the group has been very important; especially their efforts to share the wisdom of their experiences with the younger members, and to help one another resolve problems.  In terms of business, the most noteworthy part has been the training she and the other communal bank members have received on how to better manage their finances. 

Cartagena is a beach community located in central Chile, very close to the port of San Antonio.  The town’s economy depends primarily on tourism, especially in the summer and over holidays, during which many people come from nearby Santiago (Chile's capital).  The town's population nearly doubles in the summer because of the tourists, whose business is a large source of income for the commercial and service providers in the area.

loans.use: Purchase bread-making ingredients and equipment

loans.name: José Ramos

texts.es:
José Ramos tiene 38 años D. edad, es casado y tiene un hijo dependiente, resiD. en el caserío Positos del distrito D. Mórrope, una zona rural dedicada principalmente a L. agricultura y que se encuentra bastante alejada del pueblo central, está situada a una hora y media D. L. ciudad D. Chiclayo.

Se dedica a L. comercialización D. arroz: el adquiereeste producto y algunos D. sus derivados (como el polvillo) a los diversos molinos D. L. zona para luego venderlos por sacos a las bodegas y establecimientos D. L. zona donD. vive y D. zonas aledañas. El negocio le brinda algunos ingresos estables con los que trata D. mantener a su familia. Adicionalmente se dedica a L. crianza y venta D. animales

José desea ampliar su negocio adquiriendo más arroz para aumentar sus ventas y percibir mayores ganancias, esto, aprovechando que es temporada se cosechas en L. región y que este producto baja D. precio en estas semanas, para lograr su objetivo ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito D. 1500 nuevos soles que le ayuden a realizar su objetivo.

José es unhombre bastante trabajador y responsable, en L. zona donD. vive sus vecinos y conocidos le consideran una persona tranquiL. y responsable.
texts.en:
José Ramos, 38, is married and has a dependent son. He lives in Positos, Mórrope district, a rural area mostly dedicated to farming since it is quite far from the main town. It is located an hour and a half from the city of Chiclayo. He is a rice merchant. He acquires this product and some of its derivatives, like “polvillo” (rice powder) from the various mills in the area and then sells it in sacks to the stores and establishments in the area where he lives and in adjacent areas. The business produces stable income with which he tries to support his family. In addition, he raises small farm animals for sale. José wants to expand his business buying more rice to increase his sales and thus his profits. He does this now taking advantage of the fact that it’s rice harvest time in the area and rice prices decrease during these weeks. In order to reach this goal, he has asked Edpyme Alternativa for the first time for a loan of 1500 new soles. José is quite a hard working, responsible man. Where he lives his neighbors and acquaintances consider him to be a level-headed, responsible person.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a married lady with three children. She has been farming for the past twenty-one years, rearing chickens and dairy cows. She sells milk in her local community and has one employee.

Josephine joined Maarifa group in Faulu Kenya so as to get financial support. This is because the group members guarantee each other’s loans. In the group, she also saves her money.

Josephine is requesting a 30,000 KES loan to buy animal feeds. She hopes that, someday, she will have a decent home.

loans.use: To buy animal feeds

loans.name: Ruto

texts.en:
Ruto is 30 years old and married with one 6-year-old child. His child is currently attending school. Ruto is a farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for ten years and has employed one farmhand. His main products are milk and tea which he sells locally.

Ruto has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 20,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He hopes that with the extra income from the sale of milk he will be able to pay school fees for his child.

In the future, he would like to build a dairy unit for his dairy cows. He is happy with the work of Juhudi Kilimo.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia B. is from the village of San Jose, Mambajao, Camiguin, Province. She is 45 years old. Sonia is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Sonia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs to sell. Sonia has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2009, Sonia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Sonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Sonia is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Sonia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en: Wilma E. is a married woman who lives in Portland, Kahumayan, Danao, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store business. Her husband Tomas E., who is 48 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn a living, and helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children, who are 15 and 22 years old and currently going to school. Wilma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Wilma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,400, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future, to help her husband with their daily needs, to improve her living conditions and to educate the children. In the photo is Wilma and her husband. Wilma E. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: as working capital for his mechanics business

loans.name: Mamadou
