She's applying for a loan to buy a wider range of sneakers because demand peaks this time of year and sales increase considerably.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La Sra. Guillermina es casada, su marido es el señor Ramón Benítez, tienen 1 hija de 9 años de edad que estudia en la escuela. Ella trabaja por las mañanas en casas de familia como empleada domestica y por las tardes vende zapatillas de forma ambulante, recorriendo diferentes barrios de la ciudad. Guillermina es una joven dinámica y emprendedora; tiene como consigna adquirir un vehiculo para poder aumentar sus ingresos y así poder vender mas variedad de artículos.

Solicita el crédito para poder comprar mas variedad de zapatillas ya que en esta época del año son bastante solicitadas y las ventas aumenta considerablemente.

loans.use: Buy sneakers at wholesale prices for resale.

loans.name: Iris

texts.en:
Iris has an eye for fashion and has found the perfect way to turn this talent into a business. Because her home city of Ayacucho, Perú is located rather remotely in the Andes Mountains, it is difficult to find a variety of clothing and jewelry. For this reason, Iris makes the monthly ten hour bus trip to the capital city of Lima to buy beautiful clothing and jewelry which she carries home to Ayacucho and sells to friends, family, and customers. Much of the time she receives orders, for example for a summer sundress, and with this direction she uses her good taste to pick out a nice outfit. 

Iris has been involved in this business for the past 10 years, and is very content. The way she currently does business allows her much freedom and the ability her to travel, an aspect she loves. She is currently entering the busiest time of year. In Ayacucho, at the end of the school year (which is in January), there are many graduation parties. From those completing primary school to high school graduations, families celebrate this happy occasion. A staple of these parties is the perfect graduation dress. Beginning in December, orders begin pouring to Iris from mothers wanting the perfect graduation dress for their daughters. Thus, Iris is planning a special weeklong trip to Lima in December, when she will buy many dresses to bring back to Ayacucho. An economic boost in the form of a small loan is what makes projects such as this possible for Iris. It is also what has made the support of her family of four daughters possible. Without such loans, the growth and success of her small enterprising business would be nearly impossible. This is why Iris loves her village bank. It is there that she receives advice on everything from saving her money to how to better support her family. Iris is currently requesting a loan of $1025 in order to fill the many orders pouring in for the holiday and graduation season.

loans.use: To buy dresses, jewelry, and gifts

loans.name: Naziran's Group

texts.en: I live in the small town of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan, with my family. I have eight kids: five girls and three boys. Currently, three of my kids attend school. My husband manufactures stitching machines. He has hired one worker to help him in the business. Now, we need a loan to invest in our business. My other group members are: Mariam B. needs a loan for their grocery. Shamshad B. needs a loan to buy cloth for her embroidery business. Rehahna B. needs a loan for their thread and second-hand clothing business. Khursheed B. wants a loan to buy thread for their tailoring business. Rubina B. needs this loan for their cosmetics and jewelry store. All these women really deserve loans and work very hard to expand their businesses.

loans.use: Expand current business

loans.name: Mohammad Ismail

texts.en: Mohammad Ismail lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with 2 children. He has a retail shop and he has been involved in this business for more than 2 years. He wants to expand his business to make a good income so he wants to take an individual loan to buy extra materials like boxes of cookies, bags of rice, boxes of sugar, chocolates, and sweets. He is happy that he can help his family.

loans.use: To buy extra materials to complete his stock

loans.name: Griselda

texts.es:
“My husband, my two children and I used to live with my parents, we saved money to buy a piece of land and build two rooms. Upon finishing the building went to live there. We have been living in those rooms for 1 year and now we would like to build one more room as we need space and room for our children.” I am asking for a $1000 to build a room on my home.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

“Mi esposo y mis dos hijos vivíamos con mis papas, estuvimos ahorrando dinero para comprar un terreno y construir dos cuartos, cuando terminamos la construcción nos pudimos ir a vivir ahí; ya tenemos 1 año habitando esos cuartos pero ahora nos gustaría hacer un cuarto más ya que necesitamos espacio y comodidad para nuestros hijos”. Solicito $ 1000.00 dlls para construir un cuarto en mi vivienda.

loans.use: Build a room on our home

loans.name: Zoila

texts.es:
Always seeking progress, since she was young Zoila has dedicated herself to selling. Before working in her shop, she sold cheese and beef to different customers. At the same time, she also worked as a cosmetics consultant. Neverthless, she thought it wasn’t profitable to dedicate her life to these jobs. As a result, with the help of her husband, she opened a shop. Currently, she continues her two previous jobs; however, she dedicates more of her time to increasing her sales in her one and a half year old shop. She is focused on working hard so that in the future she may have a better space for her store and can increase her inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva volunteer.

Buscando siempre el progreso, Zoila desde muy joven se ha dedicado a vender. Antes de trabajar en su bodega, ella repartía quesos y carne de res a distintos clientes. Paralelo a eso también trabajaba como consultora de cosméticos. Sin embargo ella pensó que no era muy rentable dedicarse de por vida trabajando solo en ello. Es así que con la ayuda de su esposo se animo a abrir una bodega. Actualmente, ella continua con sus dos oficios anteriores pero el tiempo lo dedica más a aumentar sus ventas en su tienda de tan solo año y medio. Ella piensa seguir trabajando duro para en un futuro tener su tienda en un local propio e implementarla con más productos.

loans.use: Increase her inventory.

loans.name: Enrique

texts.es:
Sr. Enrique Martínez is 53 years old and is married to 49-year old Venancia Cáceres. They have four children aged 27, 25, 22, and 19. The eldest is employed in a well-known business in the city, and the others are university students in Business Administration and Accounting.

Enrique raises and sells cattle. He began this work in 1972 when he was still single. After getting married, he continued with the same work but with the help of his family. A year ago he opened his own butcher's shop located on the main street of the town.

His butcher's shop is one of the biggest in the city with a large number of clients who shop there every day for meat and meat products. Currently the couple's main objective is for their children to complete their university education so that one day they can manage and expand the business started by their father.

Enrique is asking for a loan to buy cattle to raise and then sell the meat in his butcher's shop, and in this way satisfy the big demand for his products.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Enrique Martínez de 53 años de edad está casado hace 28 años con la señora Venancia Cáceres de 49 años, la pareja tiene cuatro hijos de 27,25, 22 y 19 años; el mayor de todos trabaja como empleado en una conocida empresa de la ciudad, y los demás están estudiando carreras universitaria de Administración de Empresa y Contabilidad

El señor Enrique se dedica a la cría y venta de animales vacunos, se inicio en este trabajo en el año 1972 cuando aún era soltero; luego de casarse él continuo con el mismo junto con el apoyo de su familia y hace un año inauguró su propia carnicería ubicado sobre la avenida principal de la ciudad.

La carnicería es una de las más grandes de la ciudad, posee una buena cantidad de clientes que todos los días acuden a su negocio para comprar carne y derivados. Actualmente la pareja tiene como objetivo principal que sus hijos terminen su carrera universitaria, para que el día de mañana ellos puedan administrar y expandir el negocio iniciado por su padre.

Solicita el préstamo para la compra de animales vacunos para luego faenar y comercializar en su carnicería y de este modo abastecer la gran demanda de carne que hay.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Mofulewi

texts.en: Mofulewi S. sells drinks, electronic accessories, and umbrellas in the Shibiri community. She is 27 years old and is married with 3 children. She lives in Shibiri Ekunpa, Lagos State, Nigeria. She acquired the skill of trading over two years and she has been in this business since 997. Mofulewi has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 4 years. She needs a loan of $850 to buy more drinks, electrical accessories and umbrellas to sell.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, electrical accessories and umbrellas

loans.name: Koffi Pierre

texts.fr:
Mr. Koffi Pierre A. was born on December 31st, 1954 in Lomé. He is married and the father of four. After retiring in 1997, he opened a general store in Lomé. In his store, ETS BORO, he is currently having trouble maintaining adequate stock of supplies (rice, oil, tomatoes…) and is requesting this first loan to buy 10 sacks of rice, 14 cans of oil, 4 cases of canned tomatoes, and 2 cases of soap.

This way, he will have a more attractive stock, which will increase sales.

Translated from French by Pamela Poole, Kiva Volunteer.

Après sa retraite en 1997, monsieur A. Koffi Pierre né le 31 décembre 1954 à Lomé, marié et père de quatre enfants a ouvert un magasin de vente des produits de premières nécessités et de boisson à Lomé. Dans son magasin ETS BORO, il a actuellement un problème lié à l’insuffisance de stock de vivres (riz, huile, tomates, …) et sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter 10 sacs de riz, 14 bidons d’huile, 4 cartons de tomates en boîte et 2 cartons de savons).

Ainsi il aura un stock plus attrayant pour pouvoir mieux vendre.

loans.use: Purchase of basic supplies

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Faith O. is 36 years old and married without children.  She lives in Benin City, in the Edo state of Nigeria.  Since 2005, she has been selling clothing materials and offering sewing services.  In order to expand her business, Faith is requesting a loan of $450, which will be used to purchase more tailoring materials.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials for cloth production.

loans.name: Mwajuma's Twaomba Salama Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma, 38, is married with three children between the ages of six and three. A food seller since 2005, she works daily from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. and can earn a monthly profit of about $60.

Mwajuma is requesting a loan to buy more food items including rice, maize flour, meat, vegetables and bananas for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members: Salha, Maryam, Asha and Salama.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Jorge Guillermo

texts.es:
Jorge C.  tiene una  vagoneta  con la cuál trabaja como taxi en la ciudad de La Paz y El Alto. El transporte le permite tener ingresos decentes  y cubrir los gastos familiares ya que tiene que enviar dinero al exterior (giros) porque sus hijas se encuentran estudiando en la Republica de Argentina.
Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Pampahasi de la ciudad de La Paz. 
El crédito será destinado para la compra de un nuevo motor, llantas y una reparación completa del vehiculo
Es la tercera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial nos dice que merece toda la colaboración financiera que necesite.
texts.en:
Jorge C. has a station wagon which he uses as a taxi in the city of La Paz and El Alto. Transportation allows him to have a decent income and to cover family expenses that he has to send money abroad because his daughters are studying in Argentina. His home is located in the area of Pampahasi in the city of La Paz. The loan will be used to purchase a new engine, tires and to fully repair his vehicle. This is the third time that he has requested a loan from Impro and his history tells us that he deserves all of the financial assistance he needs.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: María Eneida

texts.es:
María Eneida es originaria de Tampico Tamualipas, tiene tres hijos y es viuda. <

> Actualmente, María Eneida solicita un crédito por USD$450 a un plazo de 6 meses, con la finalidad de comprar productos naturistas que ayuden a la quema de grasas. <

> María Eneida se inició en las ventas por la necesidad de tener un ingreso extra para subsistir ya que su esposo falleció hace 3 años y la pensión que le dejó no le alcanzaba para sus necesidades. <

> La falta de un apoyo económico, ya que al fallecer su esposo la pensión que le dieron fue menor a lo que él ganaba y aunque ella trabaja como instructora física en el Seguro Social, su suledo es muy bajo. <

> En Julio de 2005, una sobrina, que es promotora de los productos, que yo María Eneidea vende la convenció a que iniciara también su propio negocio con la venta de dichos productos, le gustó la idea y empezó a venderlos entre sus vecinos y después a sus compañeros de trabajo y amistades. Realmente le ha ido muy bien, pues actualmente María Eneida ocupa el 2o. nivel de ventas y planea alcnzar el 3er. Nivel para poderse ganar un viaje por altas ventas. Aparte de los productos que ella vende, también es monitora de actividad física en el IMSS en donde imparte cursos a personas de la tercera edad. <

> ¡Los invito a que apoyemos a María Eneida quien ha demostrado muchas ganas por salir adelante! <

>
texts.en:
María Eneida is originally from Tampico Tamualipas, has three sons and is a widow.

Currently, María Eneida is asking for a loan of $450 to be repaid in 6 months, with the goal of buying natural products that help in the burning of fat.

María Eneida started in sales out of a need to have extra income to survive after her husband passed away three years ago and his pension left her without being able to cover her needs.

She lacked financial support once her husband passed away as the pension that they gave her was less than what he had earned and, even though she worked as a physical fitness instructor in social security, her salary is very low.

In July of 2005, her niece, who is a promoter of the products that María Eneida sells, convinced her to start her own business too in the sale of these products. She liked the idea and started selling them to her neighbors and, later, to her co-workers and friends. Truly, it has gone very well for her. She is currently in the second level of sales and she plans on reaching the third level so that she can win a trip for highest sales. Apart from the products that she sells, she is a instructor in physical fitness in the IMSS (Mexican Institute of Social Security) where she gives classes to seniors.

I ask you to support María Eneida who has shown a great desire to get ahead!

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of natural products to burn fat.

loans.name: Ruhin

texts.en: Ruhin has been in the tailoring business for 10 years. He is married and has three children. He was born in 1975 and lives in Baku city. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy cloth and other necessary items in order to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy cloth and other items to improve his business

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es: Nancy tiene 31 años, vive con su esposo y su pequeño hijo. Trabaja cada día para en pro de la mejora de su panadería, ella elabora sus propios panes en un horno artesanal. Su trabajo diario consiste en levantarse muy temprano para la preparación y venta de sus panes. Es un proceso complejo que va desde calentar su horno con leña, tamizar la harina hacer la mezcla, batir manualmente, bolear, controlar el tiempo de cocción del pan y contabilizar la cantidad de producción. Para Nancy la época de mayor venta es cuando comienza el año escolar (marzo – abril). En el futuro quiere implementar su panadería con maquinarias modernas, como una batidora y mezcladora. El esfuerzo de Nancy es motivado por sus hijos. Es la tercera vez que solicita un préstamo con MFP, y demostró en el anterior ciclo ser una persona puntual con sus créditos. Esta vez invertirá en la compra de sacos de harina y leña para su horno, comprará en grandes cantidades, lo almacenará para que el alza de precios no afecte sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Nancy, 31, lives with her husband and young son. She works hard at her small bakery, making bread in a traditional oven. Her day starts early in the morning so that she has time to make her bread and sell it. It's a complex process, heating the wood oven, sifting flour for the mix, beating the dough, rolling it, controlling the cooking time, etc. Nancy's strongest sales are at the beginning of the school year (March, April). In the future, she wants to set up a bakery with modern equipment. Nancy's motivation to work hard is her children. This is the third time that she's applied to MFP for a loan and she's show herself to be punctual in repaying past loans. She will use the loan to buy sacks of flour and wood for her oven. She will buy large quanitities of supplies and stock them so that price increases don't affect her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for bakery business.

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanny P., 30, and her husband, Mr. Theara Thuy, 34, who live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 2000 and have three children: two daughters and one son. Two of their children attend school and the other one is still young.

Vanny has been a silk weaver since she was fifteen years old. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a mason ever since he got married. Vanny is requesting her first loan of US$ 1000 to add to her own money to purchase construction materials for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To add to her own money to purchase construction materials for her husband’s business

loans.name: Hijos Del Dios Group

texts.es: El grupo " Hijos D. Dios " esta representado por la señora Carmen Teresa y conformado por 14 miembros que en su mayoría se dedica a la venta D. cosméticos y D. artículos como  cotillones, abarrotes, C. cola y tarjetas para celulares. La competencia en el ámbito comercial es difícil, pero los socios (as) saben salir adelante con esfuerzo y honestidad. El destino del crédito es para la compra D. insumos y materiales para poder mejorar sus ingresos y la calidad D. vida D. sus familias. Los socios (as) tienen experiencia trabajando con grupos solidaR. debido a que van cursando juntos su segundo ciclo dentro D. la Fundación Agrocapital demostrando capacidad en la administración D. los fondos otorgados y responsabilidad con sus obligaciones.
texts.en:
The "Hijos D. Dios" group is represented by Mrs. Carmen Teresa and consists of 14 members who primarily sell cosmetics and items such as paper supplies, groceries, C. Cola, and cell phone cards. The competition in the commercial market is difficult, but the members know that in order to be successful honesty and effort are needed. The loan will be used to buy consumables and materials in order to improve their businesses and the quality of life of their families. The members have experience working as a united group as they have been learning together and are in their second loan cycle with the Fundación Agrocapital, demonstrating their capability in administering their loans and being responsible with their obligations.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Malohat

texts.ru: Малохат женщина 33 лет , замужем имеет троих детей.Муж имеет свой бизнес,ларек по продаже продуктов питания.Малохат имеет две коровы которые дают молоко.У Малохат соседи покупают молоко и домашний кефир.Подруга Малохат посоветовала ей взять в кредит ещё две коровы.С которых она будет получать ещё дополнительное молоко.Для чего Малохат и обратилась в Микроинвест.
texts.en:
Malohat is a 33 year old woman, she is married and has 3 children. Her husband has his own business – a kiosk selling food products. Malohat owns two cows that produce milk. Malohat’s neighbors purchase her milk and homemade kefir (yogurt). Malohat’s friend recommended that she take out a loan to purchase two more cows, from which she can get additional milk. For this, Malohat turned to MicroInvest.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase two cows

loans.name: Chourouk

texts.en: Chourouk is a 22 year old woman who lives in Bint Jbeil, in southern Lebanon.  Chourouk has worked as a hairdresser for four years.  She also sells beauty products.  Chourouk requests a loan of $1000 from Al Majmoua to purchase products.  This is the first time Chourouk has requested a loan.  Chourouk is special because she knows how to deal with clients and is aware of the haircut fashions.  Her clients are women from the region.  When Chourouk first started her business, she didn't have start up capital.  She decided to go into business because she had experience.  In the future, Chourouk plans on open a beauty products shop.

loans.use: Purchase products for her salon.

loans.name: Brenda Dalila

texts.es:
La señora  Brenda Dalila  E.  Pérez, pertenece al Banco Comunal “PEQUEÑAS EMPRESARIAS II”, vive en el Jr, circunvalación 1215  Distrito de Tarapoto, departamento de San Martín. Es soltera y estudiante al mismo tiempo.

Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, pudo iniciar su negocio propio, empezó   vendiendo refrigerios, que ofrecía los transeúntes que pasaban por su casa, haciéndose conocida por su buena sazón e higiene en la preparación de sus productos. Tiene 02 años trabajando con el Banco Comunal.


En la actualidad se dedica a la Venta de  comidas, ofrece  desayuno, almuerzo  y  cena en un ambiente especialmente acondicionado  en su propia casa , donde sus principales clientes son los policías del penal ,estudiantes del colegio que están  ubicados cerca de su casa  y los moradores de su barrio.

Con este préstamo de S/ 800.00 que cancelara a plazo de 06 meses, lo invertirá, comprando platos, ollas, vasos, sillas, sacos de arroz, sacos de azúcar, para dar un mejor servicio y atención a sus clientes. 

Ella es la que  toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio pero cuenta mucho con el apoyo de su mamà. En lo personal, desea  tener su propio restaurante  y se siente más segura con el pago de sus cuotas. 

BRENDA, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria  y mujer.
texts.en:
Brenda Dalila E. Pérez belongs to the “Pequeñas Empresarias II” comunal bank. She lives on street 1215 in the Tarapoto District, San Martín Department. She is single and a student at the same time. With her first loan of S/. 300.00, she was able to begin her own business. She began by selling snacks to pedestrians passing by her house. She became known for her delicious food and good kitchen hygiene in preparing her products. She has been working with the communal bank for 2 years. She now sells meals—breakfast, lunch, and dinner, from a space in her own house that has been set up for this purpose. Her principal customers are the police from the jail, students from the nearby high school, and residents of her neighborhood. With this loan of S/. 800.00, which she will repay over a period of 6 months, she will invest in plates, cooking pots, glasses, chairs, bags of rice, and bags of sugar, so that she can provide better service to her customers. She is the one who makes the decisions regarding the earnings from her business, but she receives much support from her mother. Personally, she wants to have her own restaurant and she feels more secure with her loan payments. Brenda expresses her appreciation to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a businessperson and woman.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plates, cooking pots, glasses, and chairs. To buy ingredients: rice and sugar, among others.

loans.name: Richard's Group

texts.en:
Richard K. represents the Tumwesige group in Lugazi. He is a very hard-working man with a motorcycle business that he has owned for two years. He owns one motorcycle that he drives himself but plans to buy two more and employ others to drive them. 

Thanks to the loans he has received, he has been able to buy a plot of land and other household items, which he otherwise could not have owned. He needs a loan to help repair his motorcycle so that he can bring in more money.

loans.use: Repairing his motorcycle in order to earn more money.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah S. currently sells smoked fish and is requesting a loan to stock more fish for sale in order to enhance her business. She is 20 years old and married to a man who is a builder. Sarah does not have children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs including economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more fish to sell

loans.name: Kaniz Fatima Muhammad Alam Group

texts.en:
Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits & vegetables to sell. 
Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. 

Kaniz Fatima baji is the group leader of the above-mentioned ladies. They all belong to a city named Borewala, Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. Kaniz baji is married to M. A. who runs a grocery shop in the community. He has three years of experience in this business. Kaniz baji is a very hardworking lady. She runs a sewing clothes business to pay off the utilities and to share the financial burden with her husband. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s grocery shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en: Lucila N. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 59 years old, widowed, and has four adult children. Lucila owns and operates a business running a food stall, primarily selling food snacks near the school. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Lucila joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Lucila is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

location.town: San Carlos, Tukuran Zamboanga del sur

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana trabaja en el magisterio como profesora de lenguaje en dos establecimientos; vive con su padre y esposo y por el momento no tiene hijos, vive en la casa de sus padres ubicada en la zona Ciudad Satelite de la ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito lo destinará para la compra de material de construcción para refaccionar la vivienda de su padre que se encuentra con deterioros.
 
Es el cuarto  crédito con Impro, el buen comportamiento de pago permite aprobar otro préstamo solicitado por la prestataria.
texts.en:
Juana works as a language teacher in two establishments. She lives with her father and husband. They currently have no children. She lives in her parents’ house, which is located in the Cuidad Satelite zone in the city of El Alto. The loan is to buy construction materials to refurbish her father’s house, which has deteriorated. This is her fourth loan with Impro. Her good payment history qualifies her for another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cost of construction materials to refurbish her father's house, which has deteriorated

loans.name: Ngory

texts.en: Mrs. Ngory Y. is a villager in Leab village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Touch Chantha, sells ice-cream to earn money. Mrs. Ngory Y. is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizer for the field in hopes of making the crop more productive. She would use the rest of the loan to buy some ducklings to raise and breed, and duck food for them. She hopes to increase the family's income and to improve their living conditions with this loan. This couple has a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband and child are presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her rice crop and to buy ducklings.

loans.name: Anatalia

texts.en:
Anatalia A. is from the village of Katipunan, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old. Anatalia is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Anatalia owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Anatalia has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Anatalia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anatalia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Anatalia is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Anatalia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Qoriccoyllor Group

texts.es:
Los socios del banco comunal “QORICCOYLLOR”; tienen como afinidad, de que todos ellos viven en el mismo barrio, son vecinos del distrito de Santiago, dentro de la provincia del Cusco.

Nuestros socios tiene diferentes actividades, una de ellas es costurera tiene su propio taller, la otra es asistente de contabilidad de una empresa, 2 enfermeras, uno tiene su tienda de abarrotes, otra socia vende verduras y cereales en el mercado, un socio es asistente de antropología, una socia es cocinera para una institución infantil, un socio trabaja en construcción y la otra socia vende carne en el mercado. Todos nuestros socios tienen el deseo de aumentar sus ganancias, muchos de especializarse en lo que estudiaron y otros en invertir para mejorar sus ingresos, para esto solicitaron el dinero.

Nuestros socios agradecen el apoyo que les brindan mediante los préstamos y se comprometen en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido, teniendo así su primera experiencia con este tipo de préstamos.
texts.en:
The members of the “QORICCOYLLOR” community bank all live in the same neighbourhood in the district of Santiago, in Cusco province. Our members run various businesses: one is a seamstress with her own workshop, another is an assistant company accountant. Two are nurses, one runs a grocery store while another sells vegetables and cereals at the market. One is an anthropology assistant, one member is a cook at a children's institution, one works in construction and the last sells meat at the market. All our members wish to increase their revenue, many aim to specialise their studies further, while others will invest to increase their earnings using the funds requested. Our members are grateful for the support received through these loans and undertake to make their instalments in accordance with the repayment plan. This is their first experience of this type of credit.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Clapham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in various businesses.

loans.name: Elpidio

texts.en:
Elpidio, or Jhun as he is also called, resides in the village of Lawig, Lamut, Ifugao. He is 23 years old. He finished only his high school education due to lack of financial resources. So he decided to work and save some of his income so he can pursue his studies. 

Jhun is a frozen-food vendor. His parents gave him a small amount of capital to start his own business. He purchases his products in the public market of Solano and sells them at a retail price in their village by going house to house. With his sacrifices, he is able to earn a weekly gross income of 1,500 Philippine pesos (about $32). He spends some of his income for his basic needs and saves the rest for his education.  

He aims to purchase more products to sell but he lacks the capital. He would like to seek financial assistance from Kiva lenders with a loan amount of PHP5,000 for business improvement. He hopes that through this, his business will continue to progress.

loans.use: Business improvement

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Having strong family values is always a blessing. Having a common goal for the family is a grace. This is the experience of the L. family. Jessie, who is 54 years old, is married to Renato  and lives in the village of Purok 2, Barangay Carabalan, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental.  Their children, the oldest of whom is 27, and the youngest 12, live with them.

She already had a cafeteria beside her house years before she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon. It was not much but it helped defray their daily expenses and the education of their children. But it was only after she became a PD member in 2002 that her business expanded. Pouring in more capital to her cafeteria resulted in higher returns, and as she paid off the loans in each cycle, she was able to access even bigger loans because of her good track record of paying on time. Later she decided to turn over the management of the cafeteria to her husband and she set up a vegetable stand in the market to earn additional income. This new arrangement proved to be a wise decision for the couple as their family income grew. She has even started selling household commodities in addition to vegetables to provide her customers with variety. The vegetable stand nets an average monthly income of PHP 4,000 and pays for the education of her children and provides savings. From her earnings, she was able to buy a motorcycle to use in her business.

Over the years, she's kept a her good credit record with NWTF-Project Dungganon. On her previous loan, her 21st loan cycle, she borrowed PHP 25,000 and put it all into her business and fully paid on time without any delays. And for her 22nd cycle she borrowed PHP 26,000 which she intends to use to purchase larger quantities of vegetables and spices to boost her earning capacity. She is planning to invest her income from this cycle to go into the pig-fattening business and also to add to the capital of the cafeteria.  The balance will be used for house repair.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetables and spices.

loans.name: Nelith

texts.es: Nelith es una mujer colaboradora y alegre, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa, región de Ucayali, tiene 39 años y es madre de un adolescente, se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en general, pues cuenta con una bodega que funciona en su casa, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo que se dedica a la venta de madera. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mujeres al Progreso” desde hace 10 meses, el primer préstamo fue de 300 soles que  utilizó para invertir en granos, como maíz, frejol de la región, para vender en los diferentes mercados de la localidad, ahora ella necesita un crédito de 1500 soles que será utilizado para comprar productos de abarrotes y bebidas para  vender en su bodega. La meta de Nelith es ampliar su bodega y progresar.
texts.en:
Nelith is a cooperative and cheerful woman who lives in the city of Pucallpa, Ucayali region. She is 39 years old and the mother of a teen-ager. She sells groceries from a store that she operates out of her home. Her husband encourages her work and he works selling lumber. She has been a member of the "Mujeres al Progreso" communal bank for the last 10 months. Her first 300 sol loan was used to invest in grains such as corn, and beans to sell in the various local markets. Now she needs a 1500 sol loan to purchase groceries and beverages for her store. Nelith's goal is to enlarge her store and progress.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase groceries and beverages.

loans.name: Eugene

texts.en:
Eugene H. is 25 years old. He is married and has 4 children ages 4 to 8 years old. He also cares for one dependent. Eugene lives Nyamagabe Center where he has a variety shop. He employs 2 people in his business and his shop is open from 7 AM to 6 PM every day.

After having operated his business successfully for 3 years, he is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. He wants to expand his shop and buy additional goods, such as household staples and housewares, that he hopes will appeal to his current customers and attract new customers. All of these changes should result in a greater profit for his enterprise. With this profit, Eugene will pay his children's school fees and continue to build a secure future for his young family.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, bath products, and housewares

loans.name: Elus Plus Group

texts.fr:
Simon L. est président de la Banque communautaire dénommée « Elus Plus », constituée de 24 micro entrepreneurs qui ont solidairement décidé de contracter des microcrédits au près de l’IMF HOPE RDC et Kiva en vue de rendre leurs petites affaires prospères.
Simon L. 34 ans, a comme activité principale la vente des pièces électriques au marché situé au sud-ouest de la ville de Kinshasa. Il a commencé à exercer ce petit commerce depuis 1997. Il en a acquis une solide expérience. Simon vend en plein air et cherche maintenant à l’aide des prêts à vendre à l’intérieur pour éviter toute intempérie. Actuellement, l’activité lui génère un bénéfice de $380 par mois. Le prochain prêt lui permettra d’acheter quelques pièces électriques à revendre pour renforcer son affaire. Son ambition est d’ouvrir une quincaillerie dans son milieu. Simon est séparé et père de 5 enfants dont leurs âges varient entre 3 et 14 ans. Quatre d’entre eux sont scolarisés.
texts.en:
Simon L. is the president of the community bank named "Elus Plus" which is composed of 24 micro-entrepreneurs who decided in solidarity to take out micro-loans from the micro-finance institution HOPE RDC and from Kiva with the aim of making their small businesses prosper.  Simon L., aged 34, has a business selling electrical goods at the market located southwest of the city of Kinshasa.  He started operating this small-scale business in 1997 and has acquired solid experience in it.  He sells in the open air.  With the aid of loans, he is currently seeking to sell inland, so as to avoid bad weather.  Right now, his business generates a profit of $380 per month for him.  The next loan will enable him to buy a few electrical items to resell for bolstering his business.  His ambition is to open a hardware store in his area.  Simon is separated and the father of five children, ranging from 3 to 14 years of age.  Four of them are in school.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To by a few electrical items to resell with the goal of growing his revenues

loans.name: Fasiu

texts.en: Fasiu sells electrical materials at retail prices to his customers. He is 50 years old and married with 4 children. He has been in this business for a long time. He sells for long hours to enable him to put food on his table to feed his family members. He is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more electrical materials to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical materials to sell.

loans.name: Jyparkul's Group

texts.en:
Jyparkul lives on the outskirts of the city of Balykchi, which means “a fisherman”. To many people, the life in this rural area does not seem to be that attractive. There is an extremely high rate of unemployment in this city. Therefore, many young people have left the city to look for a job in the capital. Nevertheless, Jyparkul and her husband have chosen to stay. Instead of moving to the capital and starting from zero, they have preferred to create opportunities where other people have already dropped their hands.

Jyparkul is 42. She and her husband are happy parents as they have four sons. Their sons' ages range from as young as 5 to 21. Previously they had ten sheep. They invested their savings thriftily and were able to buy cows and calves. After that, they bought horses and started to trade in cattle. Now, the livestock they have include two horses, three cows, four calves and 30 sheep. Due to this business, they have been able to marry their son. Their two elder sons help the parents look after the cattle. So Jyparkul and her husband do not have any difficulties looking after that many cattle. Their monthly income from trading in livestock is up to $230. This is a good income. Jyparkul decided to apply for a loan to purchase seven or eight sheep and a calf. She wants to increase the total population of their livestock in preparation for marrying off the rest of her sons.

Jyparkul is the leader of this group. Jyparkul’s partners are: Nazgul, 36, married, with four children. Nazgul stays at home and feeds up a horse for sale. She needs a loan to buy a foal.

Aibubush, 59, is retired. Together with her husband, she raises cattle. She needs a loan to buy calves to raise.

Aizada, 26, has two children. She stays at home and looks after cattle. They have four cows and ten sheep. Her husband is a taxi driver. Aizada needs a loan to buy a horse to raise for sale.

======================================
Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3 P's concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to further your support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy sheep and a calf

loans.name: Seepa

texts.en:
Seepa is 36 and married with 1 child.  She owns & operates a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  She has 2 years of experience in this business.    Seepa needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 35 talas or US $15 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Seepa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Seepa's 2nd loan with SPBD. 

Overall Social Metric Score:*               1 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD : http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy yams in bulk

loans.name: Best Group

texts.en:
This group of entrepreneurs has chosen the name of the Best Group. They are all small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs have tried to secure from SMT/Kiva, and with this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

Isatu K. leads this group. She was born in Kono, in eastern Sierra Leone. She is 35 years old, married and has five children. Two of her children are in secondary school and three are in primary school. For the last four years, she has made a living selling baby clothes. She will use her portion of this loan to  buy more baby clothes to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy baby clothes to sell to her customers

loans.name: Carmen Emileth

texts.es:
Carmen Emileth P. M. tiene 43 años y es dueña del Restaurante Villa Concorde, ubicado en el barrio Concord del municipio de Malambo, una ciudad del área metropolitana de Barranquilla. Está solicitando un crédito de $1.500.000 que invertirá en la compra de una estufa industrial, dos juegos de mesa y sillas, un juego de ollas, calderos, y víveres.
Empezó el negocio hace 9 años cuando estaba en embarazo de su hijo menor y decidió vender sopa desde su casa a fin de ayudar a su esposo, quien para ese entonces tenía un puesto en el mercado de Barranquilla. Dos años después se vinculó a la Fundación donde realizó su primer préstamo y durante sus años con la Fundación ha visto como su negocio informal y de rebusque se ha convertido en un negocio más organizado, ya que ha podido adecuar su local, terminar su vivienda, legalizar su negocio e independizarlo de su casa. Al principio solo vendía sopa, alimento que sirve como base tradicional en la mesa del Caribe colombiano y es generalmente comprada ya elaborada: a pesar de que otras personas en el sector venden sopa hay clientela para todas. Desde hace 4 años vende almuerzos completos y ahora cuenta con mesas y sillas.
El mayor problema que se presentó fue que alguna vez se sobreendeudó a fin de adquirir un mototaxi para su esposo, no tuvo en cuenta sus ingresos y se puso por un momento en dificultades. De esa experiencia, aprendió que sí bien es importante trazarse metas, no se debe querer hacer todo el tiempo y todo debe estar muy bien planeado. Ahora espera que finalice la educación su hija mayor de 17 años que estudia  enfermería y también sueña con poder darle estudios universitarios a su hijo menor que tiene 8 años. Además espera continuar mejorando su negocio y este crédito le ayudará a aumentar cada vez más clientela.
texts.en:
Carmen Emileth P. M. is 43 years old and the owner of the Villa Concorde Restaurant, which is located in the Concord neighborhood in the city of Malambo. This area is part of the metropolitan section of Barranquilla. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,500,000 COP in order to buy an industrial stove, two sets of tables and chairs, a set of cookware, copper pots, and groceries.

She started this business nine years ago when she was pregnant with her youngest child. Carmen decided to sell soup from home so that she could help her husband, who at the time managed a vending stall at the market in Barranquilla. Two years later, she joined the Foundation and acquired her first loan. During the years of working with the Foundation, Carmen transformed her informal business into one that is more organized. She first equipped her business when she started it in her home, but then she legalized her operation and moved it into a separate location away from her house. Carmen only sold soup at first, but that was the basis for selling traditional Colombian-Caribbean dishes that her customers usually buy already prepared. Despite there being other establishments that sold soup, there were plenty of customers for all of her other dishes. She has been selling complete lunches for four years and now has tables and chairs at her establishment.

Her greatest problem at the moment is that she has been overly indebted for some time so that she could acquire a motorcycle taxi for her husband. He was not generating income at the time so they were having momentary difficulties. From that experience, Carmen learned that while it is important to set goals, one should not try to do everything at once. Instead, it is best to have a well-designed plan. She is now waiting for her 17 year old daughter to finish her education so that she can pursue a nursing career. Carmen also dreams of providing a college education for her 8 year old son. She hopes to continue improving her business and this loan will help gain more customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase an industrial stove, two sets of tables and chairs, a set of cookware, copper pots, and groceries

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
El señor Francisco H. vive en casa propia, en la zona  de Pasankeri, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposa y su dos hijos. 
El señor Francisco es constructor, hace trabajos de albañilería en casas particulares y su esposa es empleada domestica, ingresos con los que mantienen a su familia.
El crédito solicitado es para la construcción de un muro de contención que estabilice el suelo en su vivienda y no corra riesgo de rajaduras y deslizamiento.
Esta es la octava vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Francisco H. lives with his wife and two children in his own house in the Pasankeri area on the hillside to the west of La Paz. Francisco is a builder, and he does bricklaying work in private houses. His wife is a domestic employee. Their income supports the family. The requested loan is to build a retaining wall to stabilize the floor of their house and not run the risk of cracks and sliding. This is the eighth time he has asked for a loan. The completed evaluation qualifies him for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a retaining wall to stabilize the floor of their house

loans.name: Maria Elizabeth

texts.es: La señora Maria Elizabeth tiene 22 años. Su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general, por lo que tiene una excelente experiencia. Pues siempre está buscando la manera de mejorar sus ingresos con su hijo.  Por lo que su actividad económica le ha brindado lo necesario y necesita este financiamiento para la compra de materia prima como ropa interior, cosméticos, perfumes, colonias. Ella sueña  en el futuro tener una actividad más sólida con mejores ingresos, lo cual para ella seria en establecer una tienda en su lugar de habitación para no tener que dejar a su hijo al salir a ganarse la vida.
texts.en:
Srta. Maria Elizabeth is 22 years old. She operates a business selling general merchandise, work for which she has long experience. She is always looking for ways to improve her income so that she can better raise her son. The business has allowed her to provide him with the things he needs. She will use the loan to buy stocks of underwear, cosmetics, perfumes and colognes. Her greatest wish for the future is to have a more reliable source of income, a store that she can operate at home so that she doesn't have to leave her son while she goes out to earn a living.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Reynaldo's Group

texts.en:
Reynaldo O. is from the village of Brgy.Tactac, Sta.Fe, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 52 years old. Reynaldo is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Reynaldo is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Reynaldo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Reynaldo has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP whenever he sells his raised animal.

In 2010, Reynaldo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reynaldo is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Reynaldo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen is the wife of A. H. and lives in a city named Borewala (which is famous for its shrines) in Pakistan. She owns a small house with two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over 20 years.

She is a 53 year old woman, but despite her old age she does work because she loves her family and is still working to improve their standard of living. Her family loves her, too, and respects her a lot.

She has given birth to four children, three sons and one daughter. Her eldest son helps his father in his barber shop, the next to him is a welder by profession and the youngest one reads in the 5th standard grade. Her daughter is 12 years old and stays at home and learns sewing skills from her.

Her husband’s barber shop is situated in the main market and that’s why her eldest son works with him and helps him in dealing with the customers.

Parveen has been with Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva) for the last two years. Now she is applying again for a loan to purchase required items such as scissors, chairs, mirrors and creams to expand her husband’s barber shop.

loans.use: Purchase required items for barber shop

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en: Melanie B. is from the village of Gingoog City. She is 33 years old. Melanie is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Melanie makes and sells food. The main source of income for her business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Melanie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2010, Melanie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melanie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the first loan taken out by Melanie from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Khem

texts.en:
Mrs. Khem T., age 49, makes a living by selling fish. She sells the fish that her husband gives her or that she buys from other fisherman. She currently earns an average of US$ 3 a day, and she has been running her business for several years. Her husband is 49 years old and is a fisherman who works along a local river. 

Khem T. is the mother of six adult children, who are no longer in school. Two of them are now married and live away from home and other four are single. Recently, Khem T.‘s husband has not been able to fish for a while because his boat's motor has broken and it can't be repaired. 

Khem T. hopes to replace this motor but she has no cash to make that possible. Thus, she is applying for a loan to replace the broken motor.

loans.use: To exchange the broken motor

loans.name: Nuevo Renacer 2 Y 6 Group

texts.en:
Renata is the coordinator of her group Nuevo Renacer 2 y 6 (Rebirth), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in the urban slums north of Santo Domingo, an area where crime is rampant and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother of three children.

Renata is excited to be taking her third loan from Kiva partner Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business which is a beauty salon by purchasing five bags of hair products from different companies, a curling iron, plastic chairs, four gallons of shampoo and rinse, combs, rollers, hair dye and hair relaxer. She will use the profits to save towards building a new home as the one that she currently lives in has problems with leaking water.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Lematea

texts.en:
Lematea A. is 36 and is married with five children. She owns a business venture planting and harvesting taro for sale and has many years of experience in this business.

Lematea needs a loan of WST 750 to purchase weedkillers such as Gramoxone. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or approximately USD 193 per week) to improve and expand her business.

In 2008, Lematea joined SPBD and this is her 3rd loan with the organization. SPBD's loans are her only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.


About SPBD:
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and, since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join  SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates about SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase weedkillers such as Gramoxone

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of toothpaste and baby soap

loans.name: Imamidin

texts.en:
Imamidin M. is a resident of Kadamjai, a nice town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. He is 40 and married. He has three sons and two daughters. His oldest son works in a factory, his older daughter studies at a university, and the other children are at school. Three years ago with an initial investment of 3000 KGS, Imamidin and his wife began selling clothes at the market. They make 5000 KGS per month. With money received from the loan, Imamidin wants to purchase school uniforms, because the demand for them will be high in autumn when the school season begins. In the future he plans to open a sewing workshop and build a store.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase school uniforms

loans.name: Simon Kipkosgei

texts.en:
Simon is a 39-year-old gentleman. He is married to Hellen T. and they have been blessed with two children, who are now age 10 and 16.

He was introduced to Kadet by an existing member of the group that he joined. With this second loan, Simon plans to buy additional sheep that he can sell at a profit. He has been doing this business for the last 10 years and with the experience that he has gained, he has been making good profits that can sustain his family.

His future plan is to expand his business to make more profit so that he can educate all his children in the best schools.

loans.use: To buy addittional sheep for sale

loans.name: Candida

texts.en:
Candida C. is from the village of Ricoro, Gingoog City. She is 36 years old. Candida is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Candida owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing recycling services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from hauling plastics and other recyclables like bottles for local businesses and community members. Candida has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Candida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Candida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell. Candida is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Candida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Levi

texts.en: Levi is a forty-year-old man, married to a teacher and blessed with four children. He lives in Fort Portal, Uganda and has a desire to have increased income for his family. For two years now, Levi has been operating a retail shop and has been registering tremendous improvement in profits. His business dream is to sell in bulk. This is his first loan from HOFOKAM and he intends to use the loan proceeds to buy a mill to grind groundnuts for sale at his shop.

loans.use: Buying a mill to grind groundnuts to sell at his shop

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is a 37-year-old lady who is married with five children. She lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. The family she lives with is composed of nine people in a family house. Catherine operates a clothing shop in which she also does tailoring, an activity she has done for the last eight years. She started as a tailor doing her business on the streets of the town. Using the gains and support from her husband, she was able to get premises to operate from. Just like most businessmen and women, Catherine also wants to see her clothing business grow to greater heights. She wants a loan to purchase wedding gowns to rent out at her clothing shop.

loans.use: To purchase wedding gowns to rent out at her clothing shop.

loans.name: Confiance Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Confiance est un constitué de cinq  femmes mariées de la ville  San (région de Ségou), ayant en moyenne 45 ans et au moins 3  enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames et font la vente  de riz, de la  restauration et l’achat vente de diverses marchandises.
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis quatre ans. Après sept prêts solidaires tous correctement remboursés, elles sont à leur huitième  prêt et AWA T. compte acheter avec son prêt, 20 sacs de riz  pour les décortiquer. Elle effectue sa vente en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle diverse et variée.
Elle espère réaliser un  bénéfice de 42.500FCFA par mois.  En dehors du remboursement du prêt, elle utilisera  une partie de son  revenu  pour payer  les trousseaux des filles et autres dépenses de la famille. Les autres femmes du groupe comptent sur un bénéfice de 41.500FCFA par mois. 
Les femmes du groupe Confiance  ambitionnent agrandir leurs fonds de commerce et diversifier leurs marchandises.
texts.en:
The Trust group is composed of five married women in the city of San (within the region of Ségou).  The women have an average age of 45 and each has at least three children. They live within polygamous family structures and sell rice and buy and sell other diverse commodities.
Four years ago, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program to increase the scale of their business activities.  After seven successfully repaid group loans, the women are seeking their eighth loan, with which Awa T. will buy 20 bags of rice. She conducts retail sales and extends cash and credit to a wide range of clients. 
She hopes to earn a monthly profit of 42,500 FCFA. In addition to repaying her loan, she will use part of her income to pay for her daughters clothing and other family expenses. The other women in the group rely on a monthly profit of 41,500 FCFA.
The women of the Trust group aspire to increase their activities, and diversity their merchandise.

loans.use: To buy rice

loans.name: Cesar Saul

texts.es:
El Sr. Cesar C. se dedica a la venta de materiales de construcción, actividad a la que se dedica desde hace varios años y que opera bajo el nombre de venta de materiales “CESAR” cuenta con una volqueta y un camión que son de su propiedad.
Su negocio a crecido mucho a tal grado que el cuenta con cuatro empleados permanentes y es uno de los mas conocidos en la zona del Zamorano.
Don Cesar reside en la comunidad de El Pedregal, El Zamorano.
Esta casado y con su esposa han procreado 1 un hijo. 
Don Cesar es una persona muy luchadora, gracias a su negocio a logrado salir adelante con su familia.
desea ofrecerle un exente futuro a su hijo.
Las metas que el se a propuesto las a logrado cumplir.
el credito lo utilizara para la compra de materiales de construccion.
texts.en: Cesar makes a living selling construction materials, which he has done for a number of years and operates under the business name "Cesar". He owns a dump truck and a regular truck. His business has grown a lot, to the point that he has four permanent employees and is one of the best known in the area of Zamorano. Cesar lives in the community of El Pedregal, El Zamorano. He is married and has a son. Cesar is a very hard-working person, who thanks to his business has been able to make headway for his family. He wants to offer his son a better future. He is requesting the loan to purchase construction materials.

loans.use: Purchase cement, bricks and cinder blocks

loans.name: Tasleem's Group

texts.en:
Tasleem is a resident of Khanewal, a small city in Punjab Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She lives in the Faridkot area with her family in a 2-room brick house. She has been living there for over 15 years.
 
She is 45 years of age and is married to M. I.. Her son is a blacksmith. Her husband works for Pakistan Railways.
 
Tasleem is a very helpful and supportive lady. She assists her family financially by selling animals. She buys animals from the animal market at cheap rates, raises them, and sells them for a good profit.
  
She has applied for a loan from Asasah, a Kiva field partner, to improve her animal sales business. With the loan, she will buy some goats and sell them for a good profit. She started this business 8 years ago and is hopeful about the growth of her business after a loan investment.
 
She is a regular Asasah borrower and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.
  
In the photo, Tasleem is the woman holding the Asasah Passbook.

loans.use: To buy goats for her animal sales business

loans.name: Florinda

texts.en: Florinda L. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 56 years old, married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Florinda owns and operates a business buying and selling seafood products including fish like milk fish and sardines in the local community. Florinda has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Florinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell. Florinda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell like mackerel and salmon. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Florinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell like mackerel and salmon

loans.name: Awovi Mawussinu

texts.fr: Mlle  Mawussinu est âgée de 33 ans. Elle est née à Kpalimé mais habite Bè Kpéhénou. Il est dans son deuxième cycle de prêt. Elle est coiffeuse de profession  mais associe la vente de mèches , perruque et les produits de beauté. Elle a commencé en 2007 cette activité et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Elle revend en suite en face de la pharmacie à Bè Kpéhénou.  Elle demande un prêt pour acheter une douzaine de mèches et perruque et de  nouveaux lots de produits de beauté.
texts.en: Ms Mawussini is 33 years old and was born in Kpalimé but lives in Bè Kpéhénou. She is currently repaying her second loan from WAGES. She is a hairdresser by profession but also sells hair wigs, extensions and beauty products. She began this trade in 2007 and stocks up on products at the big market in Lomé, which she then re-sells in front of the pharmacy in Bè Kpéhénou. She is asking for another loan in order to purchase two dozen hair wigs, extensions and other beauty products.

loans.use: Purchasing hair wigs, extensions and other beauty products

loans.name: Verónica Yolanda

texts.es:
Verónica Yolanda Q. T., tiene 25 años, es casada, vive con el esposo y con los hijos en el  cantón Ventanas Provincia de los Ríos. Tiene 2 hijos.

Los miembros de la V.R.C. NARCISA DE JESUS se encuentra ubicada en el recinto San Temistocles perteneciente al Cantón Ventanas, esta ventanilla se dedica a labores agrícolas de ciclo corto de siembre de maíz y arroz.

Verónica se dedica a la agricultura a la siembre de maíz y arroz, compra y vende los productos en ventanas en comercial Peña y vende en la casa o en el mercado de ventadas todos los días.

Solicita el crédito para sembrar maíz, compra de insumos y semillas. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentar desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es comprar una finca.

Le gusta cocinar y lavar la ropa.
texts.en:
Verónica Yolanda Q. T., age 25, is married and lives with her husband and children in the Ventanas canton, Los Rios Province. She has 2 children.

The members of the V.R.C. Narcisa de Jesus are located in the San Temistocles district, belonging to the Ventanas Canton. This region is dedicated to short-cycle agricultural labour, sowing corn and rice.

Veronica works in agriculture, sowing corn and rice. She buys and sells her products in stalls in the Peña shopping center, and sells them from her home or in the Ventadas market every day.

She is requesting this loan for planting corn and buying supplies and seeds. The support of this loan will help her economically to supply her needs. She confronts challenges such as plagues, diseases and the varied climate. Her dream is to buy a farm.

She enjoys cooking and washing clothing.

loans.use: the purchase of supplies and seeds

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe DANAYA  est constitue de 7 mariés et 1veuve  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36  ans,  en moyenne  5 enfants, vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames au quartier SANOUBOUGOU I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur sixième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passé ont été remboursé dans de bonne condition. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de bois de chauffe et de charbons de bois à travers  FATOUMATA K., qui  compte acheter avec son  prêt, 1 chargement de camion 10 tonnes en bois de chauffe. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants Sikasso. Les bois sont revendus en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, en détail, à crédit et au comptant. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 90.000FCFA utilisée pour les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
Danaya Group ("Confidence") is composed of seven married women and one widow, who on average are 36 years old and have five children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Sanoubougou I, a neighborhood of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

This is their sixth group loan from the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their customers. Their previous loans have been repaid on schedule.

The women in this group trade with firewood and charcoal. Mrs Fatoumata K. intends to use her loan to buy a truckload of firewood (10 tons). She gets her supplies in nearby villages of the Sikasso region. She will retail the firewood, for cash and credit, to a clientele made up of men and women.

Mrs K. expects to make an average profit of 90,000 CFA francs a month, which she will use to provide for her family and repay her loan.

loans.use: To buy firewood

loans.name: Kennedy Onyango

texts.en:
